Title#1: Delaware Valley Forum - Interview With Rabbi Schachter-Shalomi
Description#1: In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is interviewed on the television show Delaware valley Forum by Dorie Lenz regarding his book, "From Age-ing to Sage-ing." Recorded in 1995, the interview is primarily concerned with how to live a meaningful life when older. Discussion topics include: The life of elders in America, harvesting the seeds sown during one's life, and exercises and guidance provided in the book.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Dialogue - Spiritual Eldering
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is interviewed on the television show Dialogue by the host, Rabbi Richard Address, regarding the concept of Spiritual Eldering. Recorded in 1992, the interview contains discussion topics such as: how to synthesize life experiences into an overarching meaning, how to save the experiences of a lifetime, how to deal with mortality, elder versus older, and trainings and the potential for becoming a trainer for the Spiritual Eldering Project.

The first medley played is related to trains. The second medley played is Hawaiian music. The recording stops near the beginning of the Hawaiian medley.

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar - Phoenix - Day 1 AM
Description#1: In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is the primary speaker at the first Spiritual Eldering Seminar in the Phoenix Arizona region. While waiting for all of the attendees to arrive, Rabbi Zalman leads the group in a chant and proceeds to explain each verse of the chant. After everyone has arrived, Rabbi Zalman asks the question which provides impetus for the seminar--what is the payoff in life? He states it is to be able to look back and say it was worth it and that we learn and can give back to the global brain. As an introduction to the morning learning, Rabbi Zalman sings Psalm 23 in Hebrew. He then introduces Barry Barkhan who defines the role of an elder in society and discusses the creation of an "Elder's Guild." After the definition, Rabbi Zalman delves into a deeper discussion of eldering and how individuals can assume credible positions as an elder within their community. The rest of the video contains two short attendee meditations, small group discussion, and full group discussion. In addition, Rabbi Zalman provides a short biography of his life responding to an audience question.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar - Phoenix - Day 1 PM
Description#1: This is the second video of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi speaking at the first Spiritual Eldering Seminar in the Phoenix Arizona region. Rabbi Zalman begins by asking people to say, "I believe," and then continue the thought silently in their minds. He believes that God’s speech to human beings is the truth that is in the universe. And that God has a language, and that language is called truth. Rabbi Zalman then moves into a discussion of affirmation, prayer, and liturgy--citing the Kedusha (a Hebrew prayer) as an example of affirmation in liturgical text. He then proceeds to discuss the Shechina (which by his definition is a local network of souls) and the notion of a global brain. Rabbi Zalman shifts to a group exercise and discussion and to bring them back to the lecture sings the Hebrew song Ba-Shana Ha-Ba'ah (in the year to come). The final parts of the lecture, he is concerned with the notion of 'futuring', statements about life, and a short discussion of the Elder's Guild. He finishes by discussing meditation and then the audience provides feedback on the seminar so far.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar - Phoenix - Day 2 AM
Description#1:
The beginning of the video begins with the conversation at the end of the first day of the seminar. When the second day begins, Rabbi Zalman begins with a song -- Hodu Ladonai Ki Tov, Ki Le-olam Chasdo. After the song, he holds a Torah and recites the Mi-she-berach prayer, asking attendees for their names to include them in the prayer. Rabbi Zalman then begins speaking about the words "Spiritual" and "Holistic" and asks the audience what their definition of eldering is. Attendees then share their homework from the previous day, including dreams and journal entries. Rabbi Zalman moves into a discussion of applied Kabbalah and relates a story of him sitting shiva (mourning) for his father. He concludes his discussion by having the attendees do a meditation on the tools for Spiritual Eldering. The video ends with a discussion of logistics for the rest of the day.

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar - Phoenix - Day 2 PM
Description#1:
The video begins with the organizer of the event thanking attendees, asking for feedback, and discussing the creation of an Elder Council for the area. After which, Rabbi Zalman begins to speak and reiterates the thanks to attendees as well as any individuals who assisted with the logistics of the seminar. He then provides a brief recap of the seminar by relating the activities that occurred throughout the seminar to planting seeds. After the recap, he has attendees pair up with an individual whom they do not know and have a discussion about the afterlife, near-death experiences, and out-of-body experiences. After the small discussions, Rabbi Zalman asks if anyone would like to share parts the conversations. Several attendees share.The video ends with the attendees singing Shalom Chaverim (Hello/Goodbye My Friends).

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar - Phoenix - Day 2 PM-2
Description#1:
This is the final video of the Spiritual Eldering seminar held in Phoenix Arizona. Rabbi Zalman begins by speaking about writing letters and how powerful it can be. He relates a story of one of his former professors at Boston University and his own family tradition of writing letters before Shabbat begins. Rabbi Zalman then cites Psalm 100 in reference to the notion that individuals do not make themselves, but instead that God makes people and people belong to God. After this discussion Rabbi Zalman has candles lit and cedar burned to set a tone for the evening prayer service. He begins with Hashkivenu, then moves onto chanting Orech Yamim (Psalms 91:16), and then requests that seven attendees come up and share their experiences from the seminar. After individuals share, Rabbi Zalman returns to conclude the seminar. The audio is very low and choppy. He concludes by discussing a way of going to bed, citing common pre-bedtime liturgy including Psalms 19:15, the Shema (a central prayer in Judaism), a single line which is commonly repeated three times, and Adon Olam. In closing, all of the attendees form a huddle in the middle of the room and chant in English.
T - 00:18:25 Zalman discusses letter writing | 00:18:26 Evening Service | 00:45:18 Bedtime liturgy

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Workshop in Florida
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi holds a workshop in Florida regarding Spiritual Eldering and Jewish Renewal. The video begins with an introduction to the concept of Spiritual Eldering and introduces several potential issues that arise for elders. Rabbi Zalman discusses the notion of psychoprophylaxis and extends the concept to preparing for death. He then moves into a discussion of the tools for Spiritual Eldering. After a discussion of the tools, he asks the participants to have a 10 minute discussion on moving from aging to sage-ing. After discussion there is an extended period of dialogue with Rabbi Zalman asking participants to share aspects of their conversations and ask questions. He then has the participants perform socialized meditation. After the meditation, Rabbi Zalman moves into a discussion of what participants should expect and strive for after the workshop. Finally, there is a long period of question and answer between him and the participants and the video ends with Rabbi Zalman singing a nigun (a melody sung with repetitious phonemes and not words) and a brief comment on Jewish Renewal.
This video has some audio issues for the first 15 minutes and only the right channel of sound is present throughout the video aside from some very brief, intermittent left channel audio at the beginning of the recording. Additionally, there are some "skips" in the video where the meditative periods were cut out and perhaps some other material removed.

Title#1: "Judaism: A Tradition in Transition" (Compass Series)
Description#1: This video is a recording of the Canadian television show Compass which aired on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. The title of the show is Compass and the segment is "Judaism: A Tradition in Transition." In the segment, four rabbis--Eugene Borowitz, Emil Fackenheim, Milton Himmelfarb, and Zalman Schachter-Shalomi are interviewed in conjunction with Markus Barth--Christian theologian. Topics of discussion include: Jewish assimilation, intermarriage, Hasidism, and antisemitism.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Feminine Archetypes in Judaism and Kabbalah
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses the feminine aspects of God. He begins by outlining what he will be speaking about and then relates a story of his time at Boston University and finding a location to do morning prayers there. Rabbi Zalman then shifts the discussion to Kabbalah and specifically the Tetragrammaton. He explains each of the letters and their multiple meanings, including two of the four letters symbolizing mother and daughter. Rabbi Zalman then discusses the use of physical movement during prayer and relates the movements to Mudra (attributed to Hinduism, Jainism, and Buddhism). After movement, he discusses breathing and cites an example from the Jerusalem Talmud. He concludes the video by relaying a story of when he changed all of the words during his prayer from masculine to feminine and how difficult it was to break from the traditional liturgy, but how enlightening it was. There is a skip in the video near the end which resolves on just a sentence more before the video finishes.

Title#1: Message to Kallah on American Politics
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is making a call to action to individuals watching. He discusses coming together and the intermingling of essences. He speaks of the government as a puppet and encourages individuals to think globally and act locally. Rabbi Zalman then encourages individuals to go out and proselytize.

Title#1: Integrating Wholeness
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is speaking to a class about the three ingredients for spiritual growth: truth, goodness, and beauty. The lecture begins with him reciting a standard Jewish prayer for the dead (El Male Rachamim) which includes reference to a recent member of his class who passed away. At 05:00 he and the class begin singing Hinei Ma Tav, a common Hebrew song. At 08:23 he begins speaking about the three ingredients for spiritual growth. He also introduces the concepts of light and shadow, which are discussed later in the video. While explaining truth and beauty, he uses a Hindu story of Krishna and Arjuna to help explain his point. At 18:00, Rabbi Zalman returns to the three ingredients and describes them all as one--dimensions of the spirit. Then, at 19:04 he moves to a discussion of the shadow and how it is related to all three of the ingredients for spiritual growth. His discussion of those ingredients continues until the end of the video where he concludes with a story of Reb Nachman of Bratslav. Title#1: Introduction to the 1988-1989 Wisdom School
Description#1:
This video contains Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and Eve Ilsen speaking about the upcoming P'nai Or Fellowship for the 1988-1989 year, which will be the second year for the Fellowship. Eve Ilsen begins by noting the importance of the fellowship and complementing Rabbi Zalman's teachings. Both Rabbi Zalman and Eve Ilsen briefly discuss their experiences the previous year and excitement for the upcoming year. Beginning at 07:30, Ilsen and Rabbi Zalman delve into the notion of a Wisdom Schoool and the intention behind the use of that nomenclature. At 09:50, Ilsen asks Rabbi Zalman to discuss the topics for the upcoming year. A discussion between the two continues where topics such as achieving the same depth of understanding outside of textual study, bringing scripture back to life by developing new avenues of understanding, and the primal myth are examined. Additionally, there is discussion of the feminine aspect of God, masculine and feminine archetypes, and ecumenical aspects of the fellowship. The upcoming fellowship is noted to be at Fellowship Farm in Pottstown, PA.
T - 07:30 Introduction | 07:30 The Nomenclature of Wisdom School | 09:50 Discussion of Topics for Upcoming Fellowship

Title#1: Message to Kallah on American Politics and Teaching
Description#1:
This video contains Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi providing a message to his Kallah (group of teachers). The first five minutes consist of a message regarding politics and urges his teachers to go out and spread their knowledge. The video then goes dark and comes back on to another message. This time Rabbi Zalman is speaking to teachers regarding how they should conduct themselves while teaching. He urges them to teach up to their students and not down. He asks that they embrace compassion over judgement. Rabbi Zalman states that the most important aspect of teaching should be that it comes from a place of love. It is only through this method that the lesson will be absorbed by the students. He has the teachers meditate with him in order to bring them to the headspace they should be in while teaching. The video ends on him reading an excerpt from, "The Dream Assembly," and cuts out mid story.
T - 05:07 Political Message | 5:07 Instructions to Teachers on How to Teach

Title#1: The Wisdom School 1990: An Interview with Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi and Eve Ilsen
Description#1:
In this video Vivian Blackstone interviews Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and Eve Ilsen regarding the upcoming third iteration of the Wisdom School. The interview takes place in Tecate, Mexico on the Jewish Holiday of Sukkot in a Sukkah (a structure built for Sukkot). The interview has an overarching theme of the unification of global thought and spirituality. While both Zalman and Eve have similar responses to questions, they both come from different backgrounds which color their beliefs. There is discussion of the collective need for spirituality, healing, and merging the teachings of east, west, and other mythologies. Rabbi Zalman notes that each tradition is still important as they all have their own teachings to offer. Both he and Eve discuss the similarities between cultures and how their search is for an underlying truth.They also both discuss the theme of the next Wisdom School--the messianic era--and both reflect back on how impactful the previous two wisdom schools have been.
T - 28:47 Questions and Answers | 28:48 A Discussion of the Previous Wisdom Schools

Title#1: Dialogue Between Huston Smith and Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi
Description#1:
This video primarily consists of a dialogue on spirituality, tradition, religious intersection, metaphysics, and cosmology between Huston Smith and Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. The question from which the discussion spawns is: How can we know what the human spirit is before we know who we are? Smith discusses the notion that religion and science are opposing forces. Zalman discusses the benefits and drawbacks of tradition and Smith continues the discussion. There are mentions and a short discussion relating to Ram Dass and Timothy Leary. Finally, Smith brings up the idea that no one religion contains more truth than another. They finish by bringing up the question of: How do we decide how much tradition to maintain and how much to eschew?

Title#1: World Wisdom Lecture Series - Dialogue Between Bernie Glassman and Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi - Bataan Faigao Speaks on His Teacher and the Five Excellencies
Description#1:
This video consists of two major parts. The first part of the video is a dialogue between Bernard Glassman and Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and the second part is a lecture by Bataan Faigao about the five excellencies and his teacher, Cheng Man-ch'ing. The dialogue between Glassman and Zalman begins with a discussion of the notion of a global village. From this topic, and questions from the audience, stems the rest of the discussion which includes the difficulty some people have in breaking down walls between religions, the internationalization of religions, limbic system responses to liturgy and tradition, and the use of languages in liturgy that are unknown by the individual reciting the prayer. They conclude with a 5-10 minute meditation. The video then jumps to Bataan Faigao who lectures for one hour on the five excellencies and his teacher, Cheng Man-ch'ing. He provides an overview of his teacher using the five excellencies as his discussion rubric.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Officiates the Wedding of David and Bonnie
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi officiates the wedding of David and Bonnie. In the video, one can observe the signing of the Ketubah (Jewish marriage contract), the Bedeken (veiling ceremony), and the time under the Chupah (the covering over a bride and groom during the ceremony).

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Officiates the Wedding of Anna and Seth
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and another officiate the Wedding of Anna and Seth. The Wedding takes place at Temple Beth Sholom in Cherry Hill, NJ on November 10, 1991. The video opens with Zalman singing to the bride and then the women singing and dancing to two Jewish songs. Then the video moves to the men doing a Tish (Jubilant Jewish Learning). After the learning, the video jumps to Zalman performing the Bedeken (veiling of the bride) and the family of both the bride and groom give their blessings. Then both officiants do a short teaching under the Chupah after which the processional begins. The groom is dressed in a Kittel (traditional Jewish all-white garb) which is common practice at Jewish weddings. The ceremony under the Chupah begins and contains a Kiddush (blessing over the wine), the ring exchange, Zalman reading the Ketubah (Jewish marriage contract), the Sheva Brachot (seven blessings said at every Jewish wedding), and finally the glass breaking followed by the recessional. The last third of the video is of the reception which has traditional Jewish dancing, Klezmer music, Israeli dancing, and speeches.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Interview on Psychedelics Part 1
Description#1: This is the first of four parts of an interview with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi regarding his use of psychedelics. He is being interviewed by a couple individuals. The interview begins with Zalman providing a brief history of his life. He then notes reading Aldous Huxley's Doors of Perception and the impact it had on him. At that point he began to look for the opportunity to try mescaline or other hallucinogens. He was made aware of Timothy Leary and Richard Alpert (Ram Dass) by a colleague in Manitoba. He goes on to relate a story about working at a Jewish camp which was followed shortly thereafter by his first experience with hallucinogens--provided by Timothy Leary. Zalman goes on to discuss the effects of his ingestion of psychedelics which include: allowing for a non-fixed perception of reality and the necessity for preparation and responsibility that go with taking psychedelics. The video ends with the interviewers noting the tape needs to be changed.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Interview on Psychedelics Part 2
Description#1: This is the second part of a four part interview with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi regarding his use of psychedelics. In this part he discusses: the perception of the Lubavitcher Rebbe with regard to Zalmans use of LSD, the times of the year that Zalman liked to use psychedelics, the difference between using LSD recreationally versus spiritually, meeting Abraham Maslow and the influence psychedelics had on Maslow, the Gaia hypothesis, psychedelics assisting with conflict resolution, the potential for psychedelic use during spiritual eldering, and the notion of using psychedelics for rehabilitation/punishment.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Leading Ma'ariv and Explaining Preparation for Prayer
Description#1:
This video consists of three parts. The first part is Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discussing mirroring God in prayer, how the names of God can generate differnt styles of prayer, and demonstrating the differing intentions, movements, and feeling of major Jewish Rabbis praying. The second part of the video is Zalman leading the Ma'ariv service (evening service) with a "congregation". There is a mix of English and Hebrew throughout the service, which follows a traditional order of prayers. Prayers can be heard in this order: Barchu, Ahavat Olam, Shema, Mi Chamocha, Haskiveinu, Hatzi Kaddish, Amidah, Aleinu, Full Kaddish, Mourners Kaddish. Throughout the service Zalman provides short teachings. The final part of the video is Zalman explaining how to prepare oneself for the morning prayer service. This includes demonstrating how to put on a tallit and tefillin with their associated blessings.

Title#1: Paul Nerenberg - Reconstructionist Shabbat Service / Kol Ami - Boca Raton, FL
Description#1:
This video is a recording of a Shabbat service at Kol Ami in Boca Raton, FL. Kol Ami is a Jewish Reconstructionist congregation. The service is led by two individuals, one of whom is Paul Nerenberg. The video consists of the entire service including a recitation of the Amidah (central prayer of the service) using English liturgy inspired by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. After the service, one of the leaders teaches about Tisha B'Av (a Jewish fast day). The last third of the video is the oneg (after service reception).

Title#1: Interview with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi on His Relationship With Thomas Merton
Description#1:
This video consists of an interview with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi concerning his relationship with Thomas Merton and beliefs espoused by Merton. There are several questions posed to Zalman throughout the interview including: How did Zalman come to meet Merton, questions of ecumenism, the removal of iconography in Catholicism, what does monasticism have to do with Judaism, and how does Zalman interpret the dreams Merton had of a Jewish woman that were documented in Merton's journal. Additional topics of discussion include an autobiographical account of Zalman's academic career, Zalman meeting Timothy Leary, time spent in monasteries, and a critique of the modern Catholic Church.

Title#1: Sacred Source: Life Death and Survival of Consciousness - Eve Ilsen
Description#1:
In this video, the perception of death in Christianity, Judaism, and Buddhism, is discussed by Ross Maine, Eve Ilsen, and Joe Levy. The first to speak is Ross Maine, whose talk provides substantial reference to Jesus and Jesus' death as a means of explaining death from the Christian perspective. Eve Ilsen is the second to speak, on behalf of the Jewish view of death. She focuses on Jewish Mysticism as a method of providing the Jewish perception of death. Joe Levy is the last to speak and focuses on reincarnation to explain the Buddhist perception of death. The video ends in the middle of Levy speaking.
05:25 Christian Perception of Death | 18:55 Jewish Perception of Death | 34:02 Buddhist Perception of Death

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi: Interview on Jewish Renewal
Description#1: In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses the tennents and impetus behind Jewish Renewal. He begins by reciting Modeh Ani (traditional prayer upon waking up in the morning) and using the liturgy as a jumping off point for his definition of Jewish Renewal. Topics discussed throughout include: how the Holocaust prompted the Jewish community to restore tradition, his experience at the Lubovitch yeshiva with Jewish Mysticism, his realization that there was a communication problem between conventional denominations of Judaism and their followers, the integration of mysticism into Jewish Renewal, the integration of feminism into Jewish Renewal, and the integration of social consciousness (including political activism) into Jewish Renewal. Summing up his views on tradition, Zalman notes the past has a vote, but not a veto.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi and Eve Ilsen in Brazil
Description#1:
This video is of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and Eve Ilsen in Brazil over a Shabbat weekend. The weekend was Shabbat Zachor (the Shabbat before Purim) 5748, (most likely February 26-28, 1988). The video chronicles their trip beginning with Kabbalat Shabat (the Friday evening service) and ending on Sunday with Zalman and Eve leaving. Throughout the video, there is a mix of Portugese, Hebrew, and English being spoken. There are interviews with attendees as well as Zalman. Parts of a Kabbalat Shabbat service, Shabbat Morning Service, and Havdalah (Shabbat Ending Service) are threaded through the video in addition to other activities that took place over the weekend.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi Leads Workshop of Kabbalah
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi works with a class on Kabbalah, Jewish mysticism, and mysticism in general. The video begins amidst Zalman discussing conciousness and mysticism. He then moves onto the notion of "The Perennial Philosophy" as espoused by Aldous Huxley before discussing the four levels of Action, Feeling, Knowing, Being. After the aforementioned topics, Zalman opens up the room for questions and discussion. Near half way through the video, Zalman does a slide show of differing geometric alignments and associations of the Sefirot. The slideshow contains imagery that demonstrates the large number of associations for each Sefira. For the last hour of the video, Zalman leads a question and discussion section which addresses topics such as: where does Zalman find fault with Huxley's Perennial Philosophy, being viewed in God's eye, reincarnation, relationships, and individual attributes of the Sefirot.

Title#1: Rabbinic Ordination of Tirzah Firestone
Description#1:
This video is of the Rabbinic ordination of Tirzah Firestone. It begins with participants taking their seats and Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi humming Amazing Grace with participants. Then Tirzah begins to give a sermon which on the Torah portion, focusing on the worlds lech lecha (lit. "go to yourself"). She discusses: going and coming, 3 souls - Nefesh, Ruach, and Neshama, and thanks many individuals who were involved in her rabbinic journey. Attendees then sing the Debbie Friedman version of Lech Lecha prior to beginning the Torah Service. Tirzah reads from the Torah and another person reads the haftarah. There are then announcements which are followed by Aleinu and the Mourners Kaddish. Tirzah's husband leads the group in song prior to them leaving the room and the video ending.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi: Interview on Jewish Renewal and How Jewish Renewal is not Judaism Lite
Description#1:
This video consists of two interviews with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. In the first interview, Zalman discusses the tennents and impetus behind Jewish Renewal. He begins by reciting Modeh Ani (traditional prayer upon waking up in the morning) and using the liturgy as a jumping off point for his definition of Jewish Renewal. Topics discussed throughout include: how the Holocaust prompted the Jewish community to restore tradition, his experience at the Lubovitch yeshiva with Jewish Mysticism, his realization that there was a communication problem between conventional denominations of Judaism and their followers, the integration of mysticism into Jewish Renewal, the integration of feminism into Jewish Renewal, and the integration of social consciousness (including political activism) into Jewish Renewal. In the second interview, Zalman addresses the notion that Jewish Renwal is Judaism-lite. His belief is that this is far from the truth. Throughout the interview he discusses: the entire global community being one, Jewish Renewal's focus on oneness, making a Noah’s ark for Judaism — saving aspects from all Jewish groups, a focus on how Jews pray, his history from the Lubovitch community to obtaining his doctorite at Hebrew Union College (Reform movement affiliated), the need to reintigrate Kabbalah into Judaism, the necessary inclusion of women, the LGBT community, intermarried couples, and non-Jews, and how Jewish Renewal views Israel.
T - 00:23:14 First Interview | 00:23:15 Second Interview
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi Teaching About Creation, Kabbalah, and Prayer
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi lectures to students on a multitude of topics. Themes for the lecture include: prayer, creation, the messiah, kabbalah, translation, and halacha versus aggada. The video begins with Zalman discussing Bereshit (creation). He leads an in-depth discussion with a heavy focus on interpretation using the four levels of Jewish exegesis (Pshat, Remez, Drash, Sod) to provide explanation. He discusses creation in the framework of Kabbalah. Additionally, he discusses the difficulty in Hebrew to English translation and its affect on how people understand texts. Zalman then moves into a discussion of Torah, Midrash, and davening (praying). Near the middle of the video he provides a lengthy explanation of Shiva Asar B’Tamuz (a minor Jewish fast day, lit. Seventeenth of Tamuz). For the last 50 minutes, Zalman jumps from topic to topic discussing: The Messiah, the four levels of interpretation, the four worlds, and Halacha (Jewish Law) versus Aggada (Legend).
00:02:11 In-Depth Talk on Creation | 00:22:37 Discussion of Prayer | 00:47:23 About Shiva Asar B’Tamuz | 01:11:59 Zalman Ties Everything Together

Description#1: This video has two different parts. The first part is a recording of a CNN World News report on an interfaith seder that was held at Beit Shmuel in Jerusalem, Israel. The seder was organized by Dolores Grey, a minister, and led by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. It brought together people of differing faiths, cultures, and races. Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi Teaching About Kabbalah, The Four Worlds, and the Sefirot
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi lectures to students on several topics. The lecture is fluid and moves between concepts freely. Major themes of the discussion include: what to save from the past and what to create in the future, Issac Luria and his teachings, Kabbalah and mystical parables, the four worlds, and the Sefirot. The video opens on Zalman discussing Halacha (Jewish Law). Shortly thereafter he moves into why there are two words for "why" in Hebrew as well as Halacha versus Aggada. After a while he then switches to a question of which Jewish traditions should be saved and which should be rebuilt. Zalman then talks about prayer and meditation as well as the necessity for interdenominational and interfaith connections. Finally, he discusses human connectivity to God, Sefirot and their intersection with the four worlds, and the need to stay grounded in order for Kabbalah to help.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi on the Seasons, Holidays, and Prayer
Description#1:
This video is of footage shot of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discussing Judaism and the seasons, holidays, and prayer. The video is shot in five major segments - winter, spring, summer, fall, and inside - in Boulder, CO. In the seasonal parts, Zalman is filmed answering questions as well as walking around in nature. The final segment takes place indoors and consists of Zalman discussing Jewish liturgical objects, like talitot and tefillin, and then focusing on the importance of music in prayer. The video ends with Zalman and a keyboardist creating a new tune for Adon Olam.

Title#1: Raising the Sparks - A Chuck Davis Film
Description#1:
This is the film "Raising the Sparks" by Chuck Davis. In the film, Davis chronicles his journey back to Judaism through the Jewish Renewal movement. Themes discussed throughout include: why Judaism, Hebrew in Judaism, laws and commandments, Hanukkah, intermarriage and rasing children, and a pinnacle experience at a Kallah (gathering of teachers). Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is a primary interviewee, along with Rabbi Jonathan Omer-Man, Rabbi Tirza Firestone, and others.

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Seminar in Colorado Springs
Description#1:
This is a video of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi leading a Spiritual Eldering seminar. There are three major parts of the seminar. The first part focuses on the foundational theories supporting Spiritual Eldering. These include topics like: how Zalman came to see the need for spiritual eldering, Freudian psychology, the life cycle, extended awareness, the brain, mortality, forgiveness, and spirituality. The second part of the seminar has the participants doing two guided exercises with an in depth conversation about the exercises following. Topics discussed include: mortality, the spirit, mentoring, respect, journal writing, oral histories, forgiveness, and blessings. Finally, the video concludes with a group discussion and question section.

Title#1: Davenology - Prayer and Ecumenism According to Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi
Description#1:
This video consists of two separate recordings. The first recording is Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discussing "Davenology" (his theory behind prayer). He relates his history and influences of prayer and discusses how prayer in Jewish Renewal came to be what it is. Some topics on prayer discussed during this lecture include: influences from many religions, psychology, Hasidic Judaism, where he could practice new techniques, how to effectively pray in English, how to prepare for prayer, translations, affirmations, concentration, and imagination. The second recording is on the common thread between all religions. Ecumenism (with all religions and denominations) is the primary topic of discussion. In explaining the common thread and ecumenism Zalman discusses: sincerity in prayer, paradigms - specifically the organic paradigm, generic spirituality, and why to be Jewish.

Title#1: Morning Prayer with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi leads viewers through the weekday morning prayer service. This is an unedited video and as such there are retakes of some prayers. The prayer come in the traditional liturgical order, however there is some traditional liturgy which is omitted. Zalman fluidly shifts between Hebrew and English as he recites all of the prayers. Additionally, in the beginning of the video, he demonstrates putting on the Tallit and Tefillin.

Title#1: The “Jewish Secret”: An Historic Invitation from Tibet’s Dalai Lama
Description#1:
In this video, Dr. Nathan Katz reflects on his experience visiting the Dalai Lama with several other Jewish scholars at the direct invitation of the Dalai Lama. Topics covered in the lecture include: how Jews are perceived by Tibetans, how the Jewish people survived in exile, similarities and differences between Tibetan Buddhism and Judaism, an unexpected meeting with Ram Dass, and how interreligious dialogues are beneficial for both parties involved.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Teaches Classes on Psalms
Description#1:
This video is comprised of four days of teachings by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi on the Psalms. Over the course of the classes multiple psalms are recited and examined. Additionally, Zalman provides exercises for several of the psalms. Topics of discussion include: Tikkun HaKlali (Reb Nachman's selection of psalms, Hallel (praise service), books on and of psalms, psalms in houses of mourning, death and mortality, abecedarian and actrostic psalms, prayer, and Sukkot.

Title#1: Psycho-Halacha: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Provides New Interpretations of Jewish Law
Description#1:
In this video Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi provides new interpretations of Jewish law (Halacha) for students of Jewish Renewal which are dubbed Psycho-Halacha. The video is in three parts. The first part consists of Zalman discussing: gerut (laws of conversion), ishut (laws of women), defining who is Jewish, gets (Jewish divorce contracts), Jewish law on homosexuality, and haliza (Ceremony to Reject Marriage to Dead Husband’s Brother for Childless Women). In the second part Zalman focuses on Ḥoshen Mishpaṭ (laws compiled in Rabbi Jacob ben Asher's Arba'ah Turim about finance, torts, legal procedure, loans, and interest). Additionally, he talks about Beit Dins (Jewish abritration panels), the notion of a Jewish covenant, and general thoughts on Halacha. The final part of the video is Zalman speaking to the students watching and thanking individuals.
00:02:41 Gerut (Laws of Conversion) | 00:07:19 Ishut (Laws of Women) | 00:10:06 Proposes a New Way of Defining Who is Jewish | 00:18:46 Bedeken (Veiling Ceremony) and Gets (Jewish Divorce Contracts) | 00:30:45 Co-parenting Agreements | 00:33:00 Homosexuality | Haliza (Ceremony to Reject Marriage to Dead Husband’s Brother for Childless Women) | 00:39:51 Ḥoshen mishpaṭ | 00:50:18 Equitable Beit Din | 00:55:08 Covenant and Circumcision | 01:04:55 General Thoughts on Halacha | 01:07:32 Concluding Remarks (Final Segment)

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi: Jewish Sancta, Teaching on Leading Prayer, and Jewish Divorce
Description#1:
This video consists of three separate recordings. The first recording is of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi teaching a group in a synagogue about Jewish liturgical objects, what he refers to as "Jewish Sancta." Some of the themes are: tallitot (prayer shawls), tefellin, the synagogue setting, menorot, the ner tamid (eternal light), the torah scroll and its associated objects, shofarot, and mezuzot. The second video is of Zalman teaching three women about how to be a ba'al tefilah (prayer leader). Throughout the recording he discusses: improvisation, rehearsals, spontenaity, the use of English, and creating genuine feeling among congregants. The final recording is an in depth discussion between a few individuals and Zalman regarding his development of a new get (Jewish divorce contract). There is substantial discussion throughout and a large amount of material is covered. Topics of discussion include: get d’oraitah versus get d’rabbanan, his development of a new get, the working model, and the shtar (contract).

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi: Laws of Jewish Divorce and the Development of a New Get
Description#1:
In this video Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and several others discuss Jewish divorce law, specifically the documents and logistics. The first part consists of Zalman explaining an Halchic get and how it has traditionally been performed. After, he moves onto a discussion of how to create a "new" get for the Jewish Renewal movement. Extensive discussion takes place among all of the participants and references to Talmudic and other rabbinic teachings is frequent and interspersed throughout the video.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Discusses His Relationship with Chabad
Description#1:
In this interview, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses his relationship with Hasidism and more specifically, Chabad. The interview chronicles his upbringing, introduction to Hasidism, and work with Chabad. Zalman discusses Chabad in the 1940s and 50s, his relationships with both Yosef Yitzchak Schneersohn and Menachem Mendel Schneerson, among other leaders. Additionally he discusses the first time he took LSD with Timothy Leary and the resulting ostracism from within Chabad. The video is a fluid mix of English, Yiddish, and Hebrew.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Teaches How to Pray the Morning Service
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi leads viewers through the morning prayer service. The film is titled, "Prayer From the Heart: Davvening With Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi." He shows how to put on a tallit and tefillin and then proceeds to move through the order of the service, with short explanations along the way.

Title#1: Birthday Message to Ma Jaya | Documenting the Star K Slaughterhouse in Colorado
Description#1:
This video has two distinct and unrelated parts. The first segment is a birthday message from Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi to Ma Jaya. He wishes her well and sings a Mi Sheberach (healing prayer) to the tune of happy birthday. He finishes her message with blowing the shofar (rams horn). After the message, there is near 30 minutes of no video. The video picks up with a documentary on a Star-K (Kosher Certification) slaughterhouse in Colorado. The documentary chronicles the creation, and problems faced, in the creation of the Kosher meat co-op.
00:03:48 Birthday Message Concludes | 00:32:59 Documentary Begins

Title#1: Restringing Workshop Part I
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi works with participants on connecting with God. The video opens with Zalman asking participants what their agendas are for the day. He then proceeds to lead the group in songs and explains why they are singing. After a few songs, Zalman has the participants sit in pairs and do an exercise where they recite lines to each other. After the exercise, he asks for feedback and then has the participants pair up again and do another exercise. Then Zalman explains Hitbodedut (self-secluded meditation made famous by Reb Nachman of Bratslav) and how to do it. He has the participants go outside to practice this type of meditation. After hitbodedut, the participants return to the classroom and Zalman spends the rest of the video discussing aspects of the Sefirot. The video ends abruptly in the middle of Zalman speaking.

Title#1: Restringing Workshop Part II
Description#1:
This video is a continuation of Restringing Workshop Part I. It begins with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi reciting and singing the Kedusha (a central component of the Amidah prayer). He has participants join in. Zalman then moves onto discussing the Sefirot and their associated attributes. After some time, he has the participants stand with a partner and evaluate their partners posture using the Sefirot as guides. Zalman then moves into a discussion of the connection between the soul and Sefirot. The second half of the video consists of Zalman guiding participants through two exercises and describing a third exercise to practice at home. The video concludes with the participants blessing each other.
00:06:20 Zalman discusses the Sefirot and their Attributes | 00:36:07 Posture Evaluation Using the Sefirot | 00:48:05 Connection Between the Soul and Sefirot | 01:04:39 Exercise of Opening the Heart | 01:21:41 Exercise in Visiting Younger Self | 1:31:13 Description of Exercise to Visit Future Self | 01:44:37 Conclusion

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Interview on Y2K
Description#1: In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is interviewed on his perception of Y2K (the perceived disaster associated with computer date conversion). Topics of discussion include: fears and hopes regarding Y2K, why the crisis is different than other crises, the potential for Y2K to be a unifying event, the individual versus the community, the Jewish perception of Y2K, and the intersection of religion and Y2K.

Title#1: Joseph Schachter Interview by Yad Vashem
Description#1:
This video was developed by Yad Vashem in 1994 as one of many Holocaust Survivor Testimonies. This video chronicles the experiences of Joseph Schachter and his family before the rise of the Nazis, the years leading up to the Holocaust, fleeing Nazi occupied areas, living as a refugee in multiple locations, and finally making it to the United States in 1941. Joseph provides an excellent chronology of his families experiences and their context within the surrounding environment. He discusses fleeing Vienna and becoming a refugee who lived in Antwerp, multiple locations in France, and then settling in New York with his family in 1941. For the most part, dialogue is in English, however he frequently uses Hebrew, Yiddish, German, Flemish, and French when relating the stories.
00:02:08 Interviewer Begins Questions | 00:15:38 Joseph Begins Discussing His Own Life | 00:22:58 Reminisces about the Nazis Marching on Vienna | 00:53:25 His Mother Arrives with His Sisters in Belgium | 01:24:11 Family Escapes Through Marseilles on a French Steamer to the Virgin Islands

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Noon Lecture Series
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman dedicates this talk on transpersonal sociology to Bela Abzug who passed on today. He starts by discussing origins of the current consciousness. He presents the evolution of models—Sigmund Freud, Behaviorism, Carl Jung, Humanistic Psychology, Viktor Frankl, and Transpersonal Psychology. He says we are still missing something: the realization of our connectedness. Something happens when there’s a group energy. He talks of thought form created by a group of people in Tibet-- that with a certain focus of energy a different field of form is created. Could a morphogenetic field be constructed with intent? He talks of other planes of being. He quotes the work of Swedenborg’s Heaven and Hell and Maximus Homo, and the body of god having many parts. We know about these morphogenetic fields, that there are beings on other vibratory levels. We must shift the template of society, create places where people can meet and learn upaya. He talks of Osho, Peyote ritual people, the sweat lodge, and night services he conducted in the 1960s. He talks of share flow and posits the world being in this state. When conflicts aggregate something new emerges. We can shape this—we can do lifecraft on the emerging aggregates. He talks of eye contact meditations and making this sharing happen. When we are processing, we could learn how to get on one frequency. He mentions Ken Wilbur and his work on what keeps smaller groups together. He discusses psychic research and what happens in telepathy. Parapsychology studies have been done on individuals but what results we would get with groups—a possible amplification of current? He talks of Baal Shem Tov and Michael Hutchison and the brain mind technology; training the brain in different states of being. This has been done with individuals, but what would happen with groups? Would it enhance telepathy? He would like to see retreats like compassion stretchers. People grab initiative from you-- what is or may not your task. He says we need to have mediums to read us and screen us in such situations. He suggests working with the zodiac circle. Separate people by zodiac and breathe together. Is there more harmony? Can we send currents upstream to slow the current of time?

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Eventing Lectures
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses how to experience Kabbalah and the anatomy of God. He begins with dressing in robes and singing. There is singing and chanting throughout the film. He discusses the history of Kabbalah, the Zohar and its esoteric lineage. He talks about the story of God, the infinite, and the creation of the world. He talks of when the mystery of the trinity came about, the evolving planet, and the aspect of God that fills the world. He discusses angels. When we do something good and have good intention, we create an angel. Angels bring lessons that come to us on many levels. He talks about levels of attunement, a grateful mentality, and how moving across these levels raises our consciousness. He discusses perpetual adoration, quieting, thankfulness and blessings-- and gives examples of these in various prayers. He discusses the resurrection of the dead in relation to the body and the soul.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Noon Lecture Series
Description#1: Rabbi Schachter-Shalomi is introduced. He quotes Ocatvio Paz: Life is plurality. Death is uniformity. By eliminating cultures life is weakened. Every culture that disappears diminishes life. We must clear the reductive method template from our minds. We cannot cut a thing out. We must see it organismically-- we need one another. Everything is in a community, from the smallest electron; everything is in relation to each other. The chain of life is accomplished by a chain of consciousness. Organisms live in community. Cells talk to each together, which indicates consciousness. If there is an intelligence greater than ours, it’s important to communicate with it. It’s good for the cells to live in obedience to laws of the organ, and the organ to the organism. He discusses the time scale. Being integral to the planet means flowing into the planet. The speeding of time is not healthy for the planet. He questions how we can collaborate with the world at its best pace. He illustrates and explains Figure Ground Reversal. Religions arise from a ground-- something happens in the global plain-- every tradition says this. Each time this happens the figure religion steps out of its ground. Judaism is ground for Christianity, Buddhism from Hinduism. Each phase is a further development. He discusses synchronism. Take religions, mix them together and make one religion. People who have had a primary experience are not afraid of this. The more we share, the more we’re sharing one mind together. He references Ken Wilbur. What are the transformative and translated values of religion? Much is translation but both are needed. What are the tools to make us experience what we need? Each religion has roots to the land and Earth. It is necessary to consult ecology.  We need elements that come from the Earth to interact with the Earth. We don’t have the brain cells of a global brain—we need synaptic connections and greater connectivity. Historically, religions haven’t wanted to have anything to do with each other. But dialog is needed to connect with one another. We need this dialogue between religions. We need devoutness—to know how to use liturgy and contemplative tools. We must exchange information. There’s something pulling us to greater consciousness and greater connectivity.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Noon Lecture Series
Description#1: Reb Zelman is introduced. He discusses how religions are affected by the new cosmology. He talks about time. We don’t pay much attention to the textures of time. The flow of shared and inhabited time has speeded up vital processes. The sympathetic nervous system process, where we live under the pressure of time has speeded up. The parasympathetic process, where we spend our rest, and sleep, restores us again. Today, time for this has been diminished, and we need to spend more time in this process. Time has many dimensions, but we only experience the present. We must think in ways where time is not as rigid, and attune to different time zones of awareness. There’s a different dimensionality of time from a galactic point of view, from a transpersonal perspective. Something is calling us from the future. If we would tune in to what calls us, it would be a way to handle a little of that time deficit. He discusses religions affected by the new cosmology and the challenges of theologies. Some reality maps may clash with fundamentalists. He discusses his own past belief in world creation chronology. This is happening in all religions. By what process do they update their reality map and values? How do religions keep their identities and deal with this change? There’s no room for this in rigid hierarchies. We must move from mechanistic point of view. God is within, not outside of us. Our awareness keeps growing and is a better way to know God. What’s going on behind my mind, in my awareness? Who’s minding the mind? The deeper we are, the less is it mental and more an essential way of being. In looking for God on the outside we lose the awareness that is within us and is accessible to us. We can get to a place where we can deal with time. We can find moments of eternity to refresh ourselves from that maelstrom of time disturbed.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Y.O.C 2000/5761 Rabbinic Retreat with Reb Zalmen Day 2 of 3
Description#1: The film is of day 2 of a 3 day rabbinical retreat. Reb Zalman reads various passages from a text in Hebrew, translates it to English, sings and leads chants. The subject matter is diverse. He says the mind wants to go to place of meaningful connection, and accompanied by insight, it is wonderful, as it results in other knowledge. We have many insights, but they disappear very fast. The beginner’s mind lights up like lightening but if there isn’t preparation it disappears. Insights don’t stay with us, and most times, minds have no way of wrapping around information. The study of Cabala here is important, it offers possibilities. He talks of mindfulness and looking at meditation from the Vipassana point of view of emptying the mind. We are bombarded by so much stimuli that when you’re in a pressure situation it’s easier to fill the mind than empty the mind. When you add conscious content, i.e. adding words to hymns-- it allows us to remember and to connect again to that experience. He wants to see more of this process in meditation. He discusses diversity, and that we need to remember individual differences. Many have identified with Judaism and its rules. Some lived by the rules, stopped, but want to come back. Give them the tools to make the connection again. He says everything is for the whole sake of God. God is an atheist. God doesn’t have a god. The grand sense of awe is important. With a personal approach to God, the heart connects. He asks the audience to do an exercise. Everyone pairs up, keeps eye contact for 5 minutes, and talks about the morning meeting. They keep contact with God for 5 minutes. The audience tells of their experiences. Every time we do something we give a gift to God. All doing is in the presence of God. We should know God, but it isn’t a depth of understanding. We’re not asking deep philosophical questions. Just recognize that we live in an environment that is God.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Y.O.C 2000/5761 Rabbinic Retreat with Reb Zalmen Day 3 of 3
Description#1: This film is part 3 of 3 of a rabbinical retreat. Reb Zalman is speaking to a group in ceremonial garb. He instructs the group in a prayer ritual. He asks participants for a soft murmur and other sounds as a platform for the recitation of prayers. He gives an overview of the ritual to follow. He plays sounds for the dying, then directs group to spend some quiet time, and revisit where they were on the way up from Daven—to regather “some things.” He says prayers are often not answered because they are abandoned too soon. He asks for prayers to be said for those called to service in religious education, and other vocations. Ritual singing, humming, and praying follows. Reb Zalman instructs the group in breathing, humming, and singing. The participants form a circle, bowing, singing and chanting. Praying in Hebrew and English follows. The ritual continues with the group covering their heads with shawls. Prayers are read for messianic peers; participants lay prostrate, and there is more praying and chanting. The session wraps up with Iight hearted music, dancing, removal and folding of ceremonial garb.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Mordechi Gafni - Tape 1
Description#1:
In this video Mordechai Gafni teaches a group at the Jewish Community Center in Boulder, Colorado about sexuality and eroticism in Judaism and Jewish mysticism. The video begins with Rabbi Tirzah Firestone leading the group in song, followed by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi introducing him. Gafni begins by discussing a previous divorce, leading into a discussion of sexual imagery in the Temple. In conjunction with his discussion of sexuality, he discusses holiness and their relationship. This is the first of two videos of his recorded lecture.

Description#1:

Title#1: EJS Event Tape 1 of 2
Description#1: The film starts with a group singing and moving in a circle with instrumental music. Rabbi Tirzah Firestone introduces Reb Zalman and others. She leads the group in forming a number of circles for chanting and movement. She discusses doing this to raise energy and in preparation for the large holiday coming up( Shavout)-- as a tribe we do this cyclically. We move, we chant and we raise up energy. A chant ensues "God please reveal your Torah to me." Rabbi Zalman then discusses the Torah and how people are attracted to Jewish Renewal. Further discussion ensues with both Rabbis on how we receive the Torah and how to transform it to take it to the world.

Title#1: Revolutionizing Eldercare In Our Community - Dr. Bill Thomas
Description#1: Dr. Bill Thomas is introduced. He begins to address long term care in the U.S. and the pain of seeing what is and what ought to be. He has great faith in workers, what the system does to workers and to people in the system—it’s very far away to what it ought to be. He maintains we’ve lost touch with different kinds of living, i.e.n “being” as children and “doing” as adults. If you believe you are adult forever, then you must maintain a pretense-- a life based on doing. As decades pass, it gets harder to maintain pretense of doing as an adult. The 1.6 million people in nursing homes could not keep up with adulthood. Society has made 17 thousand nursing homes because we misunderstood old age. We thought people should be adults forever. We looked at what they can’t do, not what they could be. What if our elders begin to teach us how to be? He maintains we must help society remake a new elderhood-- to redefine the later adulthood of life. Elderhood is rich in potential, opportunity for peacemaking, and storytelling—a crucial element of social conservation. He then discusses the Eden Alternative and Green Houses, Shabbaz and Shabazene, gives examples and describes one of the present models operating in Mississippi.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Reb Zalman Schachter-Shalomi 2003/2004 Lecture Series. Lecture 1 "Psalms 10/22/03"
Description#1: The video opens with background singing and Rabbi Tirzah Firestone introducing the lecture and Reb Zalman. Rabbi Zalman starts by thanking Naropa for having spiritual "labs" which are typically not offered at traditional academic institutions. He recounts always being intrigued by psalms, and that he uses them to express himself, and how they are a surefire way to God. He discusses the Christian monastery tradition of singing psalms, Gregorian chants, and the use of psalms in other traditions. He discusses more history and translation of psalms, and how the psalms became associated with music. There is recitation and singing of psalms throughout the film.

Title#1: "But What Are We? Spritual Identities of Interfaith Families" Rabbi Tirzah Firestone;  "Why Double Vision is a Good Thing" Rev. Dr. Jay Rock
Description#1:
Rabbi Tirza Firestone is introduced and begins to tell her story of living in an interfaith family.  She discusses the positives and negatives for children brought up with a single, dual or no religion.  She says there are no formulas for deciding the best scenario, and maintains that a child should be given a tradition so they can later shun the label and engage in “god wrestling.” She says we need to recover our roots and our lost layers of identity. Children need to know who they are, their lineage and the customs of their ancestors.  This helps them to form a spiritual identity, context and appreciation of the world.  She discusses how to show children rituals that bind the family and cultivate their spirit roots. She gives examples of impromptu praying, giving thanks, telling stories, and family projects.  

Rev. Jay Rock is introduced. He tells his story of growing up in an interfaith family. He maintains that accepting dual heritages and cultures does not need to lead to confusion, but can contribute to a healthy development and sharpened view of the world.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Reb Zalman For the Teachers
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses guidelines for teachers to bear in mind while in the classroom. The video starts with in an unknown language ant turns to English (1:04). Both languages are spoken throughout the talk. Rabbi Zalman mentions that students need to hear content in a transformative way. He says the work of people who teach is to raise people up-- he calls it up-leveling, i.e. teaching your subject as if it came from above. He says make room for inspiration, i.e. going off your topic if deflected by "sparks." You must become transparent and see yourself in the presence of God. The "carrier wave of love" makes it possible for teaching to be absorbed. He gives an exercise to combat the ego/persona of the person to open the heart. From this place you begin to teach. The film ends with a prayer read from the Dream Assembly.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Creating Our Jewish Future (Thursday Daytime) - Timecode window burn - Tape #1
Description#1: The second day of Our Jewish Future. Rabbi Irwin Kula introduced. He discusses contextualism and pluralism. He says everything is context dependent. We interpret the world based on context. The essential problem of the human planet today is pluralism. The average Jew is looking for meaning, connection and community. We’re afraid of diversity-- anything that’s not unity makes us nervous. The non-orthodox Jewish community needs affirmation. Liberal Jews have a fragility of identity— an insecurity and fear that their Judaism will not live to the next generation. How do you have a body politic of pluralists that includes non-pluralists? We must have room for and hear the voice of all different fringes of Jews. Divisions are within all religions. The line can only be crossed by imagining the other perspective. Pluralism differs from diversity. It is not about compromise. It’s not relativism. It’s a passion, a commitment plus openness. We need to provoke more conversations, dialogue across the various Jewish sects. We need to learn to argue. There is a moment of silence. The film shifts to individual workshops with rabbis. Rabbi Firestone asks her group to stand in shoes of others and welcome non-pluralists. We need to tolerate, include and make room for non-pluralists in our camp. She shares a list of teachings about pluralism; everyone reads one teaching. She asks the group for insights, challenges. Several other workshops led by rabbis are shown. Rabbi Joseph Telushkin is introduced. He discusses the importance of words and the underrating of their significance. The Bible underscores that words are tangible. He talks about speaking unfairly about others and to others. People are victims of this. They have been hurt by what was said to them. He discusses the temper of parents and growing up with this; and those who have problem with temper. No one can hurt you as much as those that come from who knows you best. Many families don’t forgive and forget. There is a need to reconcile within families. We should be merciful in our families.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Creating Our Jewish Future (Thursday Daytime) - Timecode window burn - Tape #12
Description#1: A continuation of the 3 day seminar at UC Boulder Memorial Center. There are 3 speakers, and classroom groups on this tape. The first speaker Rabbi Joseph Telushkin discusses anger, rage, relationships, and speaking well of others. He says many divorces are the result of worn out love due to cruel language. Anger is destructive and people believe what is said in anger. Anger is not a rational emotion, and we act irrationally. So we need to learn mechanisms to monitor it. Anger is sometimes justified, but often times it’s expressed disproportionally to the infraction. He maintains it is not unhealthy to suppress anger. Also, we should restrict an expression of anger to the issue that provoked it. He says people destroy relationships, but they have control over anger. He goes on to discuss gossip, rumors, slander, and negative untruths. He says when someone becomes associated with negative information, they become that association. We have no right to destroy reputation, and if we have anger we should proceed cautiously. He gives guidelines to help in criticizing. He asks audience to go 24 hours without saying anything unkind about anyone. He asks for audience questions (audience inaudible).  Reb Zalman comes to the stage and speaks on this topic relative to karma and reincarnation. There’s inertia in karma, one good deed brings on another. There’s no way to get out of karma, it reinforces itself. He then discusses renewal and a new understanding. Our soul knows about how we should live and behave, but most times it doesn’t add up to tradition. We’re creating a new tradition, and we must share it with one another. Prayer time and a break follows. There are smaller classroom groups led by rabbis on the film. Rabbi Irwin Kula takes the stage and discusses Jewish renewal. He talks about the changes in Boulder, the challenges of being a teacher in town, and the emerging Talmud. He says we’re living a paradigm shift. We don’t know how to articulate what it feels like yet. We must search for oneness. Paradigm change means you don’t know the next step. You leap into the abyss. We don’t know what right Jewishness is for tomorrow. It’s pathless, and every day is a new acceptance-- a turning from externals to a returning home. Go into yourself. Return home to your innermost life. Do it together, and we’ll be blessed as one. The talk ends with Rabbi Kula leading singing and chanting in a circle.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Creating Our Jewish Future (Thursday Evening) - Timecode window burn (from VHS)
Description#1: The film contains footage of the 3 day seminar held at the UC Boulder Memorial Center. It begins with showing outdoor activity: instrumental music and attendees socializing. Speakers and the community came together to discuss the planning of a new 30 acre campus of the Boulder Jewish Community Center. Some of the speakers comment on what it means to be a Jew in the 21st century, and how pleased they are that this is happening in Boulder. It seems the majority of Jews are not comfortable in the old paradigm. Boulder is an open environment yet there are challenges to be faced. Inside the UMC the first speaker is Rabi Tirzah Firestone. She talked of pulling down fences and crossing barriers. The community of Boulder is blessed-- Boulder rabbis have a fellowship and meet regularly. There is comradery here and the Jewish community offers cross denominational services for those in need. She offers a Challah blessing and leads a chant. Rabbi Joseph Telushkin talks about Jewish history and how they’ve made progress, but not ethical improvement. He says moral imagination is needed and gives a number of examples on how to cultivate it. Rabbi Irwin Kula speaks. Rabbis treat each other with respect in Boulder and this sets the tone for a hopeful experience in taking down boundaries. He discusses how to teach about being Jewish. He talks about marginal and peripheral Jews. Most Jews who tried to transform Jewish life had to leave Jewish life to do it. Gentiles in this community are needed; across history they have always come to Jewish observances. This is not a private club, but a wisdom tradition to be brought to the world. We need to widen definitions and widen boundaries.  He discusses Rosh Hashanah, the birthday of world. It is not about ownership abut out building human community. We need to open boundaries to anyone who wants to participate. The moderator discusses the new Boulder Jewish Community Foundation, The Boulder JCC, creating creating a Boulder Jewish campus on 31 acres, and building a home for the Jews of Boulder. He mentions needing help from the Jews of Boulder, and the fund raising efforts today.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Our Jewish Future
Description#1: The conference is assembled to discuss the new Jewish Community Center in Boulder and to explore a deeper meaning of mystical Judaism. He speakers are: Rabbis Tirzah Firestone, Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, and Irwin Kula. Rabbi Tirzah talks about a fear-based ideology which has caused many to leave the faith. Many left to seek higher spiritual grounds, or marry out of the faith. She feels hopeful of bringing authentic meaning to the next generation in this new community. She believes Boulder can be the forerunner of a new Judaism. Living in proximity to natural beauty, divinity is all around us. God fills this place. Experiences of awe affect us, and challenge us. We want to explore many ways of being Jewish. Imagine a Judaism affected by the natural world. If there is anywhere in U.S. where we can live this vision, it’s here in Boulder. Reb Zalman agrees. Yes, nature is the full revelation of God. He relates that what’s happening is the action of the god Shiva; but instead of destruction to think of him as the recycler. It helps to understand why things are breaking down. Historically, various maps of reality had to be scrapped and replaced with others. When you can’t stretch the old paradigm any more it needs to die, hence a paradigm shift. We should be optimistic, not anxious. He gives examples of this with organismic systems. He talks about a restoration to spirituality, a healing process, a connection to ancestors, a collaboration, and what he’d like to see in the community– a humanistic Judaism. Rabbi Irwin Kula talks about his Jewish upbringing. He talks about Jews getting hurt, and about how everyone can experience themselves as most loved. He suggests that everyone try to find what in Jewish life they most find distasteful—and think the opposite. Imagine the insight that would result. He talks about the healing that Jews need to do, the history of being hated, and resulting PTSD. He talks of the past: developing boundaries, self-hate, and an ideology that lets one demonize the other. Healing is necessary to re-own tradition on our own terms. We must widen the definitions of Judaism. We have too narrow a frame of how people mark their own Jewishness. Why are some not experiencing spirituality in Jewish tradition? What kind of connection do we have? We must ask ourselves, what in my life is most alive?
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Celebrating Sukkot
Description#1: Rabbi Schachter-Shalomi begins a chant with the Five Species celebrating Sukkot. He discusses the meaning and history of Sukkot, giving Biblical examples. He talks of the word, meaning, divine name, numerology, and food in the rituals. He mentions Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, the brain hemispheres, and chakras. He then tells a story elucidating Karma. He talks of the infinite and finite world, the 2 names of God, God and the God Head, and that we need a filter between the two. Sukkot brings in satisfaction– the bliss and joy that fills one with goodness and beauty. He then elaborates on the days of creation related to chakras and biblical prophets. He discusses the meanings of the Four Species used in Sukkot, and compares the tradition to Native American ritual. Finally, he talks of 3 God traps, and how they are used to bring in awareness and reflection.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbinic Retreat with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi (Day 3 of 3): Weekday Morning Prayer Service
Description#1:
In this video Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi leads Rabbis through a Kabbalistic infused weekday morning service. The service follows the traditional order of prayers, however Zalman has the Rabbis break into each of the individual Sefirot and their corresponding blessing in the Amidah. When the Amidah is recited, each person/sefira takes a turn reciting their associated blessing while the rest of the rabbis hum corresponding vowel sounds underneath the blessing. Additionally, there are a few liturgical differences from the traditional Shacharit service.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Naropa Institute World Wisdom Lecture Series: Meditation
Description#1:
In this video Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi lecutres to individuals at the Naropa Institute as part of the World Wisdom Lecture Series. The general topic of discussion is meditation. Zalman takes students through specific foci, such as meditation prior to the 1960s, tools for meditation, and styles of meditation. Also, Zalman makes reference to Thomas Merton, Ken Wilber, Saint Francis of Sales, and Howard Thurman with regard to their perceptions of meditation.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter Noon Lecture Series
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman discusses the contributions of those in older age. He maintains that society needs contributions from elders. He talks about his concept of “Spiritual eldering”—from ageing to sageing. He says we need to transfer knowledge between generations—and that elders can synthesize knowledge from a long life of experience. He goes on to mention the concept of “I live,” and gives examples of how elders can live deliberately, come to terms with mortality, journaling process, and imaginative exercises. He quotes Jung in the causes of depression and the road not taken. In his own life, his failures turned out to be the “roots” of his successes. So this is a time to figure out how life had meaning within a philosophical framework—thereby creating safe and sacred places. He goes on to discuss spiritual intimacy, reconciliation, forgiveness, and past anxieties relative to the purpose and meaning of life. The film ends with Rabbi Zalman playing a CD.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter Interview on Psychedelics
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman is interviewed about his experiences with psychedelic drugs and how they have influenced his work and perceptions. The film starts with recounting his early life experiences which lead up to his spiritual quest. While doing his Master's he began studying various religions and psychology. He read Aldous Huxley's "Doors of Perception," which was pivotal in his desire to experience other levels of consciousness. He describes meeting Timothy Leary at Harvard and his subsequent "experiences" with Leary. He discusses the importance of the homework done afterword. Ultimately one has to prep, digest and do contemplative work after the experience. Quotations from Martin Buber, Ram Dass, Aldous Huxley and Abraham Maslow are recounted. He believed that Maslow's Transpersonal Psychology evolved from Humanistic as a result of these experiences. He goes on to describe how we can use these experiences for mentoring in the future, especially in his work in Spiritual Eldering.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: World Wisdom Lecture Series - Rabbi Zalman Schacter-Shalomi "If Beauty Were a Verb"
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi lectures on “beauty.” The film opens in the classroom with a guitarist leading a chant: “Kyrie eleison.” The Rabbi discusses prayers and how they should be made beautiful. Beauty, goodness and truth all have a connection to the heart. When truth touches your heart, you become engaged. He follows with a definition of beauty and aesthetics, beauty of character, and moral beauty. Another chant ensues: “Oh God beautiful, oh God so beautiful.” The Rabbi continues, saying we have a hunger for beauty in our lives, and when we experience it, it pays off in endorphins and relaxes anger, anxiety, etc. He discusses art vs. ordinary experiences. He says beauty demands that it should be shared but it needs to have the balance of truth or it could be perverse. He relates the 3 faces of God: truth, goodness and beauty. He concludes with an exercise to outwardly project beauty.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Eventing Lectures
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman discusses traditions. He talks about the need for discipline, that it enables us, and the Jewish disciplines and rules relating to food. He explains the laws, reasons and details of kosher rituals, their relation to energy and entropy, and its life enhancing and ennobling forces. He talks about Passover, leavened grain, days of fasting and specifics of the laws and from where the rules emanate. He talks of the Zohar, the absence of destroying or cutting trees, morphogenic clearing and the Gaia hypothesis, that earth is alive. He coined the term “Eco-Kosher” a consideration of being less Kosher strict and more environmentally conscious. He gives examples of rituals at Passover and discusses ecoculture.

Title#1: Part One The Rabbi and Ma
Description#1: The film opens with the frame: “In loving memory of Ethel Green.” The setting is outdoors at sundown, in front of an altar at the Kashi Ashram. It begins with Indian music, singing, chanting and prayer. Jaya Ma talks of her sister-in-law Ethel Green, and dedicates the altar to her memory. Prayers ensue and she introduces Rabbi Zelman Schachter-Shalomi. He discusses the architecture of the altar and points to its various depictions and how they also have meaning in other traditions. He stresses there are places where all religions are represented, and that they are all intrinsic and necessary for the totality of the planet. He takes olive oil and touches the symbols on the altar. There are various singers and instrumentalists, and more chanting in several languages. Ma Jaya speaks of largeness of the Rabbi’s God, and that every religion is represented here. Finally there is a ceremony in a boat with flowers and fire.
