Title#1: Tape Two: Zalman Discussing the Sefirot
Description#1:
In this video, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi instructs a small group on the Sefirot and Kabbalah. Over the course of the lecture and subsequent discussion, Zalman provides students with explanations of each Sefirah and associated attributes. Attributes discussed include: colors, archetypal names, body parts, days of the week/of creation, and Jewish holidays. Additionally, he reminices about teaching Kabbalah at Temple University. The final third of the video consists of questions from participants and answers from Zalman.

Title#1: Ram Das & Zalman
Description#1: Ram Dass is being interviewed in the video. He recalls past times with Rabbi Zalman, the speeches they gave together in New York, and the stories that the Rabbi told him, i.e. one about burial grounds in the Holy Land. He goes on to recount the experiences at Millbrook with Timothy Leary and Rabbi Zalman. In sending a message to the Rabbi he says: you and I are the survivors of that era and if you want to make psychedelics a spiritual practice, we have to stand up for it—it’s what we could do as elders. We shouldn’t be afraid to stand up for it.

Title#1: Jews and Gurus featuring Dr. Nathan Katz
Description#1: Dr. Nathan Katz explains the motivation of Jews who seek other spiritual paths, and the perception of a lack of spirituality in organized Jewish life. He begins by asking: Why do so many Jews abandon their faith, especially those who are seeking spirituality? Why is there such a lack of understanding of and appreciation of Jewish mysticism? He states that t is alarming and disturbing at how few Jews are living Jewish lives. He says in the 60’s and 70’s many stopped going to synagogue as people had a spiritual longing. They felt they had no other options but to seek out gurus. Some explored and came back. He discusses oral tradition and broken esoteric lineages. He talks about the lives of Jews who are prominent Buddhists. Questions from the audience are addressed.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Dialogue On The New Hebrew Book
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is interviewed by Rabbi Ruth Gan-Kagan. Rabbi Zalman first asks Rabbi Ruth why she wanted to become a rabbi and why she sought to study with him. She wanted to learn both the old and new ways. She asks him the same question and he begins to recount his beginnings in the yearning for knowledge and where this comes from. He talks about paradigm shifts and how we needed to shift to a larger cosmology-- from a masculine perspective to the masculine/feminine. He says that after the Holocaust this was needed to rebuild. He discusses the role of Kabbala, and that we need to nourish the heart, mind and soul of the person. He recounts the leaders who influenced him and how he learned from other disciplines. He quotes: “Your God is true” to all religions disciplines.

Title#1: Peace: Jewish and Islamic Perspectives
Description#1: A discussion at Chatauqua in Boulder, CO June 19, 2004 between Ibrahim Kazerrooni and Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi on perspectives of peace. Ibrahim and Reb Zalman light a candle and meet in friendship. Both make statements of faith in Yiddish and Arabic. The Rabbi points out that they both have the same religious, cultural, and social issues. He states there is one God-- true oneness. Ibrahim says we cannot change the issues in the Middle Ease but we can build bridges here, by initiating dialog. We cannot have peace if there is disequilibrium—as long as we harbor hate, dislike or bigotry, one cannot become an ambassador for peace. Once we achieve peace within ourselves we can translate it to the environment around us. We are all cousins of different descendants. Reb Zalman concurs and elaborates on his statement—and they both believe that creating peace here may have an effect globally.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Satsanga with Gurudev and Rabbi Zalman Schachter
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and Gurudev Shri Amritji are introduced by the Chairman of the India Project. The Rabbi is credited for bringing spirituality to religion. Instrumental music and Hindu chanting follow. The Rabbi gives a review and discusses his movement of Spiritual Eldering. They both go on to talk about chanting, and how it brings us into harmony with each other to be of one mind and one rhythm—creating an uplifting in the world. When we overcome individuality by coming together, healing happens and creates a divine flow. They go on to discuss competition vs. collaboration in business models and the need to create a structure that will fit the emerging cosmology. Gurudev states moving toward spirituality is moving toward integration and that growing together is the answer to all problems. The Rabbi discusses growing old and that help is needed for the many that do not know how to do it. Gurudev discusses the past and future as being the same as the present. They end with the Rabbi leading a chant and prayer.

Title#1: Making Matzot with Reb Shlomo Carlebach in Eugene, Oregon
Description#1: The film shows an outdoor gathering of adults and children outdoors singing, chanting, clapping and making matzo.  Everyone present is involved in the process.  The Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach is present.  The process is shown, from hand and utensil washing, table covering, mixing and rolling dough and baking in an outside wood burning stove; a smoker is seen in operation.  There is singing in Hebrew and English throughout the film with guitar and banjo accompaniments. English chant: I am within you, all around you, I am the universe, my presence lives in you.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schacter Shalomi Ramdass
Description#1: Ram Dass interviews Rabbi Zalman and they reminisce and discuss various topics. They recall when they were in New Delhi visiting temples. They discuss the Middle East, and Zalman talks of how Israeli Jews can relate to Palestinians, how two arch enemies must learn to get along with each other; that we must see the other person as a human being and see their pain. He refers to Hindus and Moslems living together in India. They discuss the cosmology of Judaism and most religions being laminated. When caught in an existing paradigm, how can others hear you? We’ve isolated ourselves from the pain of others. Ram Dass says some don’t want to use their pain to awaken. When faith gets stronger dying into the sea of suffering is possible. Zalman talks of the “36 necessary people” and how they are needed today. Ram asks him if his identity has changed since Vienna. He talks of his time then and his identity over the years. He discusses how renewal came about and those with Jewish background seeking a higher consciousness, and how changes came about. Zalman is asked to talk about his mentor and how he reconciles discrepancies between himself and his mentor. He talks of taking the baton, yet being uniquely himself. He feels inside, that he is not responsible for anything else but that. He feels his mentor witnessing his unique expression of dealing with compassion, mercy, tenderness, love, emptiness, and the like.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: The Ten Sephirot Rabbi Zalman Schachter Tape 1
Description#1: Film 1 of 3 on the 10 Sefirot. The film takes place at an animal sanctuary. Reb Zalman is outdoors speaking to group about shedding. He instructs the group to stand up and let go of things from the week. He hums and sings with the group. He talks of the tree made up of so many ancestors. Everything is unfolding just as it should. He discusses the number 7 and examples from the bible and music, and why it is so powerful, and relations of 7s. He gives examples of chanting and prayers with numbers, and asks, how are we relating to the world?  He reads prayers in Yiddish, followed by chanting, and discusses the 2nd and 3rd chakras. He notes that the Siddur includes animals in davening. He instructs the group to look at animals on the sanctuary and pick one they can relate to. Chanting follows. He says some information in Kabbala related to explicit and implicit spirituality, is not translated. He discusses how divine names should be vocalized, and talks of pronunciations in Kabbala. He talks of the Hebrew alphabet and the structure of Sefirot. When drawn 22 paths go from one Sefirot to another. He discusses the 10 vowels and 22 consonants in Sefirot. He talks of the path of 32 coming and going and becoming 64 hexagrams representing the path. He talks of how language is made, and how God communicates the 32 paths of wisdom. He discusses and instructs the group on pronunciations. There is power in vowels, consonants, and word sounds. He talks of colors related to Sefirot. If you have understood Sefirot you can look at yourself to see if you’re in balance.  He instructs the group in davening and tells them to read a psalm 7 times in various ways: chanting, theatrically, with love and compassion, perfection, gentleness, and allowing the text speak. The session ends with a Torah reading.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: The Ten Sephirot Rabbi Zalman Schachter Tape 2
Description#1: Film 2 on the 10 Sefirot. Rabbi Zalman discusses the Ten Sefirot. He starts with the book of Leviticus and talks of impurities and the Cabbalist view. We need purification and recognition that everything has a shadow cost. When you pay the shadow costs you restore equilibrium. Zalman then sings in Yiddish and chants from the scrolls. There are prayers for the dead and group members read from the Torah.  He talks of the 7 days of creation and the lower Sefirots. More readings from the Torah ensue. Zalman talks of the therapies and job of the therapist in breaking through a sudden opening, inserting a wedge in that nanosecond. He relates this to Hokhmah; helping and healing at this moment of truth. He discusses Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur. Yom Kippur is Keter--how to forgive.  What karma we would build up if we didn’t have this day. After Yom Kippur, we start again from fresh. After a break he instructs the group to break up in groups of 7, to have conversations as role of the Sefirot as if you’re the representative. Zalman sings and plays small organ type instrument. He talks of the 7 days of Sukkot, and there is a reading and Hassidic interpretation. He talks of dimensions and parameters of Sefirot, and doing Kabbala for corporate teams. Zalman relates the functions of a space ship to the 10 attributes of Sefirot. He discusses binary and ternary forms to business models. He discusses the social philosophical issues that come out of Sefirot. Each one brings dominant function so they will blend. He talks of creating coalitions. He gives the example of the 4th day of creation and the luminaries. The moon makes itself smaller to accommodate the sun. Two kings must share one crown. It’s the same way with religious parties. He proposes the use of Sefirot to solve political, social, philosophical issues. Here’s a language, apply it, ask what can you contribute? Perform your dominant function. Determine how do bring it together so it will blend and not break.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: The Ten Sephirot: The Tree of Life Rabbi Zalman Schachter Tape 3
Description#1: Film 3 on the 10 Sefirot. Rabbi Zalman answers questions about the Kabbalistic views of Sefirot and deciphering on which vibratory level one is operating. He discusses the vessel of Malkuth, and offering to the prophet. He talks about the colors and vowels related to Sefirot. He instructs the group in movement, and they move in various slow dances in a circle to solemn music. He discusses telepathy, and dancing on the inside vs. outside. He then instructs the group to take any sentence or phrase in Hebrew or English and begin to repeat it. He asks group to put energy and intensity into this, then add movement and gesture, and to further engage in someone else’s harmony. Now do it as a love offering to God. Finally take over the prayer for the whole planet, for Hesed. The group chants with movement, then reads passages and prayers. He instructs another activity—to form groups of 7. Each person chooses one of the lower 7 Sefirot. He asks them to tune in to the awareness and wisdom which is not the individual, but the group mind. [The film breaks here.] Now the group is dancing and creating music using hand instruments. Several dance in the middle of a circle, and are encouraged by others. Zalman now draws trees on the flip chart. He illustrates the Sefirots and where they intersect. He talks about vowels and syllables and explains the correspondence between the Sefirot and the 4 worlds. He draws a tree and superimposes another on it. He discusses how one tree overlays the other until it comes down to the world Assiyah. He instructs the group on how to draw the 10 Sefirot within the tree, giving metaphors. He directs them to apply the template in every multiple of 7.  Finally, the rabbi gives instruction on wrapping and putting on teffilin. He discusses the teffilin set and its meaning relating to the 10 Sefirot, and the 4 worlds of Kabbalah.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: The Ten Sephirot: The Tree of Life Rabbi Zalman Schachter Tape 4
Description#1: Film 4 on the 10 Sefirot. Rabbi Zalman and the audience chant in groups, and act out the tree of life. Members read passages, offer intentions and prayers and chant alternately. Zalman prays to turn around all negativity. He passes around a “talking stick” and instructs the group to reflect or focus on davenening, Sefirot, etc. Members share their thoughts and sentiments, witnessing to each other. Zalman discusses the definitions of words and interpretations in Sefirot and Genesis, and traces history from animal sacrifices to verbal prayer, and to mindfulness. He talks about the 4 worlds In Sefirot. He discusses external and internal realities, good and evil, parodies, and shadow costs.  He says we must talk “to” the living God. He says we have sundered one aspect of God for another. But all we know of good and evil is in one God. He creates everything, including evil. He creates light and darkness. Evil has a function in the universe. If God is good why is there evil? Evil that is instrumental lets us see different situations. There’s no negativity that doesn’t have utility. Zalman illustrates and discusses various ways to look at the 10 Sefirot. He talks about a middle projection, long or short, linear, or one on top of the other, a foreshortened view. He gives the group homework.  He instructs them to bring back a model of the 10 Sefirot in a 3 dimensional way. What does it look like from the inside? How would you engineer that? So everything on the tree remains integral but see how you can integrate being in a space that we can inhabit. He then talks about the ideal synagogue and integrating the 10 Sefirot into the architecture. In building an agency for Jewish renewal, he says to imagine the synagogue as a pilgrimage place. It starts at the place where we enter into the world. We could see back to origin of species. We absolve our ancestors. He describes other passages of Sefirot likening them to the Stations of the Cross. Finally, Zalman directs the group to chant, make their way up to Keter and give each other blessings. The group chants and moves about and embrace each other.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Tape 3 S-Firot #2 / Why Pray ; Lama
Description#1: Reb Zalman is leading a workshop and speaking to participants. He begins with humming a melody, then asking the group to hum, followed by singing with words. He begins by saying that as Jews, we don’t engage in enough dialogue with fundamentalists. He says it’s important for us to have good strong dialog in faith, and that being born again doesn’t belong to one tradition. Jews committed in faith should have a connection with all people who have faith. He discusses Hebrew words, roots, meanings, an how to use words in the masculine and feminine. He talks of the experience of prayer, and asks, is it the praying that brings this out or is it just a universal feeling? He discusses what happens in prayer or songs as vehicles. With verbal prayer-- to speak is to take a lesser form of communication. Sometimes prayer in word form takes you away from relating to God. The question of using of Hebrew vs. English in practice is discussed. How much of work should we do in Hebrew? There is a difference of opinion. Meaning is important. Something is transmitted through the word. What is the holy word in Hebrew? Discussions ensue of how much Hebrew should be used. He asks this of those coming from other traditions. He wants the vibrations that come with Hebrew. Are there certain chords within us that responds to the written tradition? When you’re in a tradition the original language may open you up to that tradition. The group discusses their experiences with reading and chanting in various languages. Zalman asks participants to imagine that the rest of their religious lives would be in Judaism only. He asks them to arrange in groups of triads where 2 people discuss, and 1 person records for 5 minutes. The groups then report on their discussions. He then asks the group to perform the same exercise but ask: Is prayer that necessary in your life that you program it as a high priority? Groups are formed in triads again to discuss this question. The groups report on their discussions. Zalman ends the session with asking everyone to do Daven.and
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Tape 4 The People Tree/ Inner Year Cycle
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman and a group are gathered in an outdoor setting. He instructs the group to form a physical tree, and to make sounds in various tones. He says every holy day contains something of the other. He points out the various holidays and explains the relationship between them.  He begins with the months and goes through the year, and relates the holidays to sounds and chanting. He instructs the group in chanting and singing sounds. The group sings and moves in a circle. They progress through the calendar and continue to act out the holidays. He discusses the 12 months of year and 12 permutations of the divine name. He talks about every month having a different name, and that we must understand the months and time as it passes. God must have an interface-- that is a divine name.  Every year a new name needs to appear.  Every time we sin we pierce the name of God. When Yom Kippur arrives, the old name is so pierced that God has to discard it. To bring about atonement, we pray to the new name. This is the day when karma gets canceled. It’s the regenerative power in the world. He talks about the level of words and numbers, God names and the covenant of the 13 attributes of mercy. By saying them, God forgives. When the divine name arrives, a vessel must be made. At the equinoxes we thank God for the seasons. He talks about the rhythm of the seasons and the holidays, and the month of Marcheshvan, when there are no holidays and we can reorganize. He talks about Hanukkah, Purim, and the full moon, and a cyclical point of view. He discusses counting Sefirot 49 times, and how doing this reveals the issue at hand. You work up questions in the 49 Sefirot days for which you need a revelation. He discusses the 3 rings in the Holy Land and the day of the death of Abraham. He asks, What if we were to get together with Christians, Muslims and pray-- what a holy thing this would be.  He recalls a time when he went to visit Abraham’s grave and describes his interactions with the keeper of the grave, and recounts the story.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Digesting the Holidays/Prelude to Telepathy, Tape 5
Description#1: The film opens with Rabbi Zalman and a group seated in a circle at a gravesite in a wooded area. The Rabbi is discussing circumcision and how he believes that a Moslem should be present at all circumcisions (the Bris). There is discussion among the group. The camera moves to a gravestone (07:55) "Suh Ahmed Murad Cristi. Samuel L. Lewis 1896-1971." There is footage of people moving around the grave site and talking among themselves. The scene turns to the indoors with instrumental music. People form a circle and a speaker in the center gives an inspirational talk.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is interviewed about "Paradigm Shift"
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman is interviewed about his book "Paradigm Shift." The film opens with the Rabbi singing. He defines the concept of paradigm shift and gives historical examples of when they occurred and how they are usually defined as heretical. Generally a panic reaction occurs at the time and a restructuring is needed. He discusses good v. evil in his mode of the 4 worlds. He discusses the masks, or permutations of God and accepts them all. He discusses people having holy experiences but most often not accepted by traditional churches, and that Jewish Renewal makes room for new breakthroughs. He goes on to discuss the growth part of God, Godding, and creation. He says God is process, a dance between creator and creating. He goes on with concepts of sacred sexuality, the Godding of God. Finally he addresses women, feminism, and the feminine aspect of God.

Description#1: Bawamuhai Yaddeen discusses God, why he sent Moses to the world, and how he placed compassion in the heart to create peace in all life. He says God is neither male or female, the soul is neither male or female, and grace & wisdom are neither male or female. He concludes with a blessing.

Title#1: Zalman Gems Perspetives on Becoming a Sage Elder The Inner Work of the Sage
Description#1: Reb Zalman and Eve Ilsen speak at a workshop about eldering and sageing. The audio for Eve Ilsen was not audible, so is not reviewed. Reb Zalman begins with guiding participants in chanting and singing. One of the ways to gain blessings for good intentions is being in union with one another, in lifting our voices. He discusses the need for elders in our society. He says we have made progress in the elder arena but our progress lacks wisdom. Elders are creating sageing centers to come to terms with their mortality. He asks: what makes you sad about dying? It is the right time for something. When something is in right time we’re in the flow. When we have yielded to the way life wants us to go, it is surrendering to divine providence. He says eldering is badly needed. In the past, we didn’t have good models for a complete life. In sageing you live out the contemplative part of your life. In the Fall season of life you learn how to harvest life, and give back. Mentoring is important at this time. With sageing you’re going with the flow. He says there are tools are for this. One tool is social meditation, talking and sharing with each other; that is, spiritual intimacy—recognizing spirit in the other person. Regarding wisdom-- you can learn it, and acquire it. The best learning we do is from our mistakes. Wisdom is gained from experience, and experience is gained from our failures. He talks about opening up the heart and of consciousness. We should share what happens to us. It creates a sacred bond. He discusses letting go at the end of life, which is important to spiritual eldering. The awareness that death can be a friend-- can be helpful. He says that meditating in certain places enables transformative cognition. In order to do inner work we should go to a sacred place. A sanctuary is the best kind of contemplative place. In a comfortable place, we can carve out an inner space, a place filled with compassion. When we don’t know what we’re thinking or feeling, socialized meditation is useful. He advises shared meditation, to have partners. He instructs the group to pair up and leads them in an exercise.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rebbi Zalman Schachter Eve. Lecture
Description#1: Reb Zalman talks about the Genesis creation narrative. He says some statements in the Bible cannot be taken literally, but should be treated like poetry, figuratively, or connotationally. He mentions instances that are allegorical, parables. The Bible is filled with commentary and some things cannot be translated. The stories have a mysterious level of interpretation; that of imagination and grace. He says the Cabalists go deeper into this in the book of Zohar. When the Catholic mass was celebrated in Latin, certain parts were chanted. Chants are very important with connotational language. The way words are chanted tells us if we should apply them literally or in another fashion. Melody also tells a great deal. By reducing things to a tone we already speak, they lose their meaning. Words can mean more than one thing. The Rabbi reads passages of Genesis and discusses possible translations and allegories. Before the existence of the alphabet, a syllabic system existed, i.e. cuneiforms utilizing 350 symbols. This system was difficult to learn, and people who could read it were often seen as sorcerers, magicians. Stories in the oral bible not the same as those in print. He talks of early biblical lineage and sibling rivalry. He tells the story of Joseph and his coat of many colors. He points out that the biblical sibling rivalry shows us how difficult it is to partner, not as dominance, but steering together. The story tells of how deeply important it is to work together. He tells of other biblical stories and their meaning.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter noon Lecture Series
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses domesticating peak experience. Can we replicate conditions necessary for these experiences? He talks of steering our consciousness, our bodies, raising our spirits, and the future of spirituality. He suggests we need to have designer made spirituality. How do we design strategies for survival, ecstasy and peace on earth? How do we get to raising consciousness? He discusses the theories of various authors, such as: Jean Houston, Gerald Heard, Itzhak Bentov, Victor Frankl, and Abraham Maslow. He talks of “domestication” and looks at various traditions. He recounts the lifestyles of saints and their limiting of life to raise consciousness. We need to create rounded people who do not withdraw but let the world in. He suggests creating R&D task forces to explore expanding of the mind. Transpersonal psychology and labs in spirituality are needed. He asks: what should go into the graduate school we are dreaming about? He proposes getting every spiritual cookbook and trying the recipes. Try to create shortcuts and better initiations-- to come out with a catalog of doable spiritualties to be explored by individuals and groups. For example, using the modalities of dance, poetics, environmental science, color, incense or pheromones, hypnotherapy and invoking mantras that draw you to the holy arc. Also brain mind machines—we need advice on the level of brain waves that puts us into harmony.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter Eve. Lecture Series
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses how to experience Kabbalah and the anatomy of God. He begins with dressing in robes and singing. There is singing and chanting throughout the film. He discusses the history of Kabbalah, the Zohar and its esoteric lineage. He talks about the story of God, the infinite, and the creation of the world. He talks of when the mystery of the trinity came about, the evolving planet, and the aspect of God that fills the world. He discusses angels. When we do something good and have good intention, we create an angel. Angels bring lessons that come to us on many levels. He talks about levels of attunement, a grateful mentality, and how moving across these levels raises our consciousness. He discusses perpetual adoration, quieting, thankfulness and blessings-- and gives examples of these in various prayers. He discusses the resurrection of the dead in relation to the body and the soul.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Sage-ing Workshop with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi
Description#1: Second part of a 2 day workhsop. Reb Zalman asks the group to do an exercise. One person begins a sentence and another finishes it. Decide on a topic and take 5 minutes. Keep eye contact, touch hands, let hands dance to the music, or read a book of psalms. Chanting gets you out of yourself and allows partnering. The group then shares their experiences. Eve Ilsen discusses aging and contemplative arts. You must exercise creativity and develop these tools before they are needed. Social roles drop away and we need to discover who we are essentially. She talks about Alzheimer’s and dementia and asks, where is that part of the person that isn’t there? There’s an opportunity to explore to find the rest. She questions what is possible to bring this back and talks about various tools such as meditation, poetry, writing, dance, etc. Zalman discusses a spiritual lab in which a student asks, what is the best religion for me? He advises philosophical homework and gives some techniques to help with this. He addresses topics the group has noted on a whiteboard. He discusses the elderly and how policy does not fulfill their needs. He talks of helping children accept parents’ mortality, and giving them permission to let go. He talks about pain and suffering and the element of needing pain. Eve Ilsen then gives a technique for feeling pain, thanking that feeling, and sending blessings in. Zalman talks about spirituality, dementia and depression. For depressions of despair, instead of trying to get out of it, we need to touch the bottom to get back up. He says going into the deep gives you a chance to rise. We should feel sorry for ourselves-- bring the petition to God in experiencing sorrow. Two other speakers read text and poetry. The group forms a circle and Zeb leads in singing and clapping to a song. Zeb discusses centering prayer, spiritual eldering and how to receive blessings. He talks of the Zen Peacemaker Order and Roshi Bernie Glassman. The group forms a circle and Zalman instructs them to share good intentions. Learning to bless one another will allow the part that’s the “sage” in you will come alive and get activated
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Reb Zalman in Akron , OH
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi is introduced. He starts by distinguishing those who are old vs. those who are elders. He talks of attunement. One being can create vibration in another; if one vibrates the other will start. The function of creating enthusiasm and energizing one another is so powerful. This helps us to become elders. He talks of learning how to pray from a praying person, in the presence of someone who vibrates, of that which is divine. As a divine being in a living body, we get divinized. Spiritual intimacy conversations is a process that turns people from merely aging to sages. We’re habituated not to look at mortality, protecting life at any cost, until it doesn’t work anymore-- when the body starts shutting down. In later life we must make peace with mortality. This opens up looking at the rest of life, a whole vista of life yet to be. There are no models here that a person spent time harvesting what their life was all about by ordering it, considering it, getting meaning out of their own life story. Making peace with it ends up an arena of work that people can do with their futures. We must sit and think over what it was all about, and put the light of consciousness over one’s life. It’s never too late. The greatest joy is to mentor a younger person. The ability to give counsel is a special gift, to be present when they talk of their hopes and dreams. We need to create new models to give feedback to the next generation. He suggests starting the skills you need to become an elder- meditation, how to make amends, and fixing things of the past. You must understand the function of your life regarding the planet, or it will be hard to say goodbye without feeling cheated. You must do philosophical homework. You must see part of yourself as a cell of the global life; that you fed back to the planet. He talks of Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, her work and near death experiences. We should become aware of this and talk about it, i.e. sharing with an entity not in the body. We need to leave a heritage, and look back and say we’ve completed that which we came to do. Questions from the audience are then taken. The session ends with Zalman leading singing in English and Hebrew. An instrumental group plays and dancing is encouraged.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Reb Zalman
Description#1: Rabbi Schacter-Shalomi is interviewed and discusses integrity in eldering. When a person elders, there’s an echo—a sense that all warring parts make peace; wisdom is the result and it provides a sense of calming. To achieve integrity, one must achieve an internal sense of being part of the global brain, offering an awareness of the universe which integrates with that of all other beings. Integrity in relationships can be a celebration of mutual forgiveness and letting go. He talks of December work and preparing for one’s passing. He reviews death rituals of the past and discusses the inner work of the dying person; how one can retain integrity yet dis-identifying with the body. This integrity gives consolation in knowing the fruit of one’s existence is given back to the universe. He discusses the importance of trans-denominationalism in eldering, and that every religion & species is needed for survival. The work of the elder is to serve with that mindfulness, and every tradition has images, words and tools which could help in this work. He sings a prayer, then discusses various angels and demonic beings. In eldering, one should accept the powers of being which are being offered.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: [Eldering and Forgiveness]
Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schechter-Shalomi discusses eldering work and forgiveness in the context of coming to terms with mortality. Without forgiveness, eldering work cannot be done. He explains that in forgiveness work, one must start with simple as opposed to global issues. When you have unforgiveness you create an armor around it. Forgiving is a sense of letting go—a release of energy. He describes 3 stages: a simple “excuse me,” taking the opposition to see what it’s like, and atonement—becoming one again. He then recites the forgiveness prayer. He goes on to discuss eldering work and the eldering spirit.

Title#1: The New Sage-ing Center
Description#1: The film consists of alternating stills with text and video, and background flute music by R. Carlos Nakai. First slide: The New Sage-ing Center sponsored by South Bend Memorial Hospital's Leighton Center. The Sage-ing Center is based on the teachings of Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi founder of the Spiritual Eldering Institute. Title#1: A Time for Spirit: 3rd Annual Conference on Conscious Aging
Description#1: The film is of the closing panel and ceremony of the 3rd Annual Conference on Conscious Aging. Ram Dass introduces a panel of 6 and they all comment on what participants should take from the conference. Ram Dass says: Aging is a unique stage of life with its own curriculum, not a continuity of what life was. It’s a time to use experience as a vehicle to work on spirit and growth. A part of you is the living spirit that is just present. Not moving, growing, or diminishing—it just is. We must cultivate that place; from there the dance of aging is very different dance. The time of aging should be used to work on one’s consciousness. Keep an open awareness to be able to dance through age and death. Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi says: Make an allocation of time and space that you will give to this work. To keep motivation in a right place he suggests doing outreach. Make a list of conscious maintenance. Ask what the body and the mind need, and raise your ecstasy count. Make note of your peak life experiences. This will turn to gratefulness. Do forgiveness work. Lighten your load, it will give you joy. Lilias Folan says: There is constant renewal and many ways to renew the body, mind and spirit. Take time for this each day. Take gratitude home. Soften your heart each day. Have gratitude for small things. Breathe gratitude and love into the heart. Rev. Matthew Fox says: Aging is a special opportunity for elders to do the spiritual work of nurturing the divine seed that is in all of us. One way is by the voluntary simplifying of our lives. It’s no too late to start over. We must connect to joy again. When souls and lifestyles are simplified-- joy comes in. And by that our species can reinvent itself in the world. Baba Olatunji talks of his upbringing in a Nigerian village. What you become is the sum total of everyone around you. He is always at home. One spirit rules the whole universe. He says: become an irresistible force against an immovable object. Only spirit is what we are. That’s an assurance, as when you have it you don’t need to be afraid. Judith Duerk: Take home the silence that came between the elder circles and sharings. That time gave us a chance to soak in each thing that was said. Feel the deep sense of quiet and space in between things. Let it make sense of itself in terms of your own life. Just hold it quietly in your hearts. Let the weekend filter into yourselves, and let it slowly speak its truth to you. Audience questions are then taken. The 2nd conscious aging award ceremony is bestowed to Baba Olatunji for his contributions to conscious aging. Each of the panelists displays one final ceremonial act. Chanting, yoga, mindfulness and drumming lead the audience in participation.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: World Wisdom Lecture Series Reb Zalman Schachter-Shalomi-Opening the gate to the Future Dee Coulter-Qultivating a Neurdogy of peace
Description#1: Two lectures are on the film. First Rabbi Shacthter-Shalomi discusses Y2K and the opportunities we have to start anew. He says we can’t expand into the next millennium unless we leave the old behind. We should start with the Zen Beginner’s Mind and ask what’s impacting us from the future, and that we should be ready for whatever’s calling us. We should work for the life of the planet, as the ego is running rampant, we’re consuming our resources, not living in harmony with it. We must let go of our selfness. If we become aware of the moving force in the life of the planet we become better partners in the process. He discusses a new program at Naropa—The Center for Engaged Spirituality. The most crucial question for us is: can we find the unified field theory for something to which everyone can have a vital connection? Much data are available for calibrating the optimal function of planetary life. We must work organically together to become agents of the healing of earth. We must surrender our minds to change our minds, and address the earth mind to learn its priorities. What would our spiritual states need to be to become agents of this? Engaged spirituality recalibrates minds to operate in the most functional way. To change the mind, surrender the mind to the greater mind of earth, to serve the purpose of the planet. In this applied spirituality center we’ll ask: What is the most optimal for the human spirit and harmony, and what is most connected with the intent of the earth? In the 2nd lecture Dee Joy Coulter discusses child development and neuropsychology in wartime vs. peacetime. Her concern is that half of children on the planet are growing up in wartime conditions. She asks: How can we bring peace to these kids? In peacetime upbringing the child is able to access the heart easily and relax. She discusses the vagal nerve pathway and the stages of child brain development and sensory processes. Throughout these stages the child is laying a foundation for mental life. She talks about what interferes in the learning process, in creating healthy social beings and the survival process. She further talks of chronic stressors, those highly susceptible, indirect trauma, impulse control and resilience.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Aging and Death in the New Millennium World Wisdom Lecture series Reb Zalman - Oacinng Seed Thoughts into the wongof Time
Description#1: There are 2 films on this tape. The first, in recognition of World AIDS Day, 1994, begins with a ceremony of 19 chimes. A panel of four discuss their experiences with AIDS, either having the disease or working in the AIDS community. They discuss how the AIDS community are our elders, help with the dying, extending generosity and wisdom in extreme and painful circumstances, humor and creativity. Grassroots development of organizations is recounted. Dying in Africa and cultural differences in native communities is presented by one speaker. Medicines in South Africa are discussed. Questions and comment from the audience ensue and a moment of silence is held. The 2nd talk is with Zalman Schacter-Shalomi (59:48). He discusses the new millennium, alternative healing methods and eco-psychology. He says we are victims of our imaginations, and that we don’t steer imagination. We imagine the worst, and have to steer ourselves out of difficult imagination.  He talks about various lineages and traditions having certain myths and that these shared visions bring in the positive outlooks. He gives examples from biology and sports for placing good intention and steering good outcomes. He talks of how with collaboration we can further outcomes with more intensity in the new millennium. He talks about thinking with the heart, not with the head, taking hold of the positive and pushing it. He asks the class what world change they would like to make and to take some time to envision it. Discussions follow.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: 7 Sermons to the Dead: In Memoriam, Mark Weisel, Part 1a
Description#1: 7 Sermons to the Dead: In Memoriam, Mark Weisel, Part 1a. Carl Jung's "Seven Sermons to the Dead". Private recording of Zalman Schachter-Shalomi reading Analytical Psychologist, Carl Gustav Jung's "Seven Sermons to the Dead,"written under the alias, Basilides of Alexandria, as translated into English in later editions of Jung's Memories, Dreams, Reflections. This recording was made in memory of Mark Weisel, a young man who had recently died, and a copy of the tape was given to his father. keywords: deep ecumenism, psychology of relgion, spiritual direction, mysticism, theosophy, gnosticism, jungian psychology
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Farbrengen on the Yahrzeit of Rabbi Yosef Yitzhak of Lubavitch, Part 1a
Description#1: Farbrengen on the Yahrzeit of Rabbi Yosef Yitzhak of Lubavitch, Part 1a. This amateur recording was made during a farbrengen (Hasidic celebratory gathering) held in honor of the yahrzeit (death anniversary) of Rabbi Yosef Yitzhak Schneersohn, the 6th Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi's primary spiritual influence as a HaBaD-Lubavitcher Hasid. Schachter-Shalomi reminisces about his Rebbe throughout, leads a group reading and discussion of his own translation of the Rebbe's "Notes for a Lecture," and discusses the meaning of a Hasidic farbrengen.Hassidut, speaker barry barkin, charlie roth, , moshav modi'in, rabbi yosef yitzhak schneersohn, 6th lubavitcher rebbe, schachter-shalomi biography.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Hasidic Storytelling at the 92nd St. Y
Description#1: Hasidic Storytelling at the 92nd St. Y. In this recording, Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses the tradition of Jewish storytelling and tells a number of stories from his own Hasidic background, especially those of HaBaD Hasidism, reads a story from his book, The Dream Assembly, and answers questions from the audience. The evening was dedicated to the memory of Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach. ball shem tov, hassidut, storytelling, rz biography, dalai lama.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism and Spiritual Eldering, Part 1a
Description#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism, and Spiritual Eldering, Part 1a. After being introduced by Jungian therapist, Douglas Canterbury-Counts, Zalman Schachter-Shalomi speaks about the connections between Freudian and Jungian psychology and Jewish mystical spirituality, leads a body oriented meditation, and speaks of the paradigm shift in consciousness that is necessary for living an integrated life. Recorded at the Center for Jungian Studies of S.E. Florida. keywords Gershom Sholem, four worlds, paradigm shift, kabbalah, jungian psychology. Series files JRRZ0001S0025N0001 - N0005
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism and Spiritual Eldering, Part 2
Description#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism, and Spiritual Eldering, Part 2. In this recording, Zalman Schachter-Shalomi introduces the work of Spiritual Eldering, speaking to the issue of thantos, 'the urge to complete' in Freudian psychology, and citing examples from Jewish and Christian mysticism. Recorded at the Center for Jungian Studies of S.E. Florida. End of life, conscious death, global consciousness . JRRZ0001S0025N0001 - N0005

Title#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism and Spiritual Eldering, Part 3a
Description#1: Jungian Psychology, Mysticism, and Spiritual Eldering, Part 3a. In this recording, Zalman Schachter-Shalomi continues to speak about the work of Spiritual Eldering, going into detail about the cycle of life, human relationship dynamics, forgiveness in relation to the High Holidays, "harvesting" one's life, "sage-ing," and our treatment of the aged. Recorded at the Center for Jungian Studies of S.E. Florida. Keywords: spiritual eldering, sage-ing, high holidays, forgiveness. JRRZ0001S0025N0001 - N0005

Title#1: On Gaia - Reb Zalman and Eve Ilsen Private Dialog
Description#1: On Gaia - Reb Zalman and Eve Ilson Private Dialog. Preparation for a Wisdom School Series. Title#1: A Sufi-Hasidic Farbrengen: Reb Zalman, Shlomo Carlebach, Murshid Siddi Hassan al-Moumani, 1a
Description#1: A Sufi-Hasidic Farbrengen: Reb Zalman, Shlomo Carlebach, Murshid Siddi Hassan al-Moumani, 1a. This is an amateur recording of an interfaith event held at Moshav Modi'in in Israel with Murshid Siddi Hassan al-Moumani, a Sufi sheikh of the Qadiri Order from Balata. It was led by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, but included Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, and Rabbi Meir Fund. In it, Schachter-Shalomi speaks about Murshid Siddi Hassan and the relationship of these two Abrahamic brothers (Islam and Judaism), and then Murshid Siddi Hassan speaks to the assembled people through Miryam, his wife (and sometimes Schachter-Shalomi as well) and leads the group in a Sufi dhikr (practice of divine remembrance). At a certain point, the original recording of the event is recorded over with Schachter-Shalomi speaking to a few students the next day about Jewish prayer and leadership. But after, the original recording continues. \Shlomo Carlebach, RZ, Ecumenicism, Sufi, Islam, Moshav Modi'in, davvenology
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Carl Jung's Four Functions of the Psyche
Description#1: Carl Jung's Four Functions of the Psyche. In this lecture from Temple University, Zalman Schachter-Shalomi introduces the topic of Analytical Psychologist, Carl Gustav Jung's Four Functions of the Psyche, i.e., thinking, feeling, sensation, and intuition, discussing each from his own perspective looking at language and faith. A single class from a course at Temple . feelings, jungian psychology, psyche, language, intuition.

Title#1: Destiny and Free Will, Part 1a
Description#1: Destiny and Free Will, Part 1a. In this lecture, Schachter-Shalomi discusses the paradoxical relationship of destiny and free-will in our lives, and also touches upon traditional Judaism and the view of destiny in A Course in Miracles. "At Shonnies" in the original label, and certain references on the audio, seem to suggest that this recording was made in connection with a weekend workshop in Florida, perhaps in association with the congregation of Rabbi Shoni Labowitz. other speaker R'Chaim Greffler.

Title#1: Jewish Meditation Conference: Keynote Address by Reb Zalman.
Description#1: Jewish Meditation Conference: Keynote Address by Reb Zalman. A keynote address given by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi at a Jewish Meditation Conference held in 1999 at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan. Schachter-Shalomi first leads the conference attendees in blessings for the planet and goes on to speak about intentionality in Jewish meditation. Hosted by Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon and Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Manhattan, New York, NY. meditation, contemplation, prayer, jewish renewal movement, biographical, slonomer rebbe, Thomas Merton, devekut

Title#1: Moshe Idel and Paradigm Shift, Part 1 (of 3)
Description#1: Moshe Idel and Paradigm Shift, Part 1 (of 3) . A talk by Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi on the paradigm shift taking place in Judaism, hosted by professor Moshe Idel in a classroom at the Shalom Hartman Institute, Jerusalem, Israel in the Summer of 1998. Some of the topics discussed include: an "organismic" understanding of religions, the "God-field," "socialized meditation," and "psycho-halachah."
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 1 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 1 of 43. Lecture 1, Part B. In this first tape of the series, Schachter-Shalomi introduces the course, "Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters" and discusses grading and class expectations. He then talks about the texts, recommends books, and begins to teach about the proper "attunement" for learning Hasidism. He then teaches the class to sing "The Niggun of the Ba'al Shem Tov," and begins to speak about the history and cultural context of the Hasidic movement, and compares a Hasidic story to one from Zen Buddhism before moving on to the story of the "failed" Messiah, Shabbetai Tzvi. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 1 of 43. Lecture 1, Part B. Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 2 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 2 of 43. Lecture 1, Part C. In this continuation of class one, Reb Zalman talks about the Ba'al Shem Tov's ascent to Heaven, Kafka's "Parable of Parables," and the theory of the triune brain. He ends the class with a celebratory niggun. Then class two begins on the same tape with Reb Zalman singing "The Niggun of the Ba'al Shem Tov." He invites questions on the reading describing the Ba'al Shem Tov's ascent to Heaven. He discusses the concept of d'vekut (adhering to God) and sings the niggun "Sim Shalom" (as done in the Ansky play, The Dybbuk) as a prelude to discussing the letter written by the the Ba'al Shem Tov describing his ascent to Heaven. This is followed by a few questions and then an explanation of the Hasidic customs around a Rebbe's yahrzeit (death anniversary). He then begins to discuss how he first became a Lubavitcher Hasid. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 3 of 43. Lecture 2, Part A. He discusses the concept of d'vekut (adhering to God) and sings the niggun "Sim Shalom" (as done in the Ansky play, The Dybbuk) as a prelude to discussing the letter written by the the Ba'al Shem Tov describing his ascent to Heaven. This is followed by a few questions and then an explanation of the Hasidic customs around a Rebbe's yahrzeit (death anniversary). He then begins to discuss how he first became a Lubavitcher Hasid. Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 4 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of Hasidic Masters, Part 4 of 43. Lecture 2, Part B. In this continuation of class two, Schachter-Shalomi continues his discussion of how he became a Hasid and tells of his first meetings with the 6th and 7th Lubavitcher Rebbes and other stories. He then tells that the 7th Lubavitcher Rebbe's yahrzeit is approaching and prepares to sing Reb Mikeleh of Zlotchov's "Melody Stiring and Inciting Divine Mercy" to which he has composed words in honor of his own Rebbe. He tells the story of this niggun's composition and sings the niggun. He goes on to read a story of the Ba'al Shem Tov and the simple people, and gives commentary on it. He ends with some announcements and a niggun. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 5 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of Hasidic Masters, Part 5 of 43. , Lecture 3, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class three with a discussion of his theory of Paradigm Shift in religion. He then discusses the Ba'al Shem Tov's aphorism which begins, "Straightforward are the ways of God," answers questions on various Jewish and Hasidic concepts, and tells stories and parables of the Ba'al Shem Tov. Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 7 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of Hasidic Masters, Part 7 of 43. Lecture 3, Part C. In this continuation of class three, Schachter-Shalomi finishes answering questions before moving on to a detailed commentary on the Ba'al Shem Tov's teaching about "The Blessing and the Curse." He then gives an assignment for the next week and sings a niggun to end the class. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 8 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 8 of 43. Lecture 4, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class four with announcements and answers a long series of questions on Jewish and Hasidic concepts. He then sings the "Niggun of the Ba'al Shem Tov" and the "Niggun of the Maggid of Mezritch." He then discusses a teaching of the Maggid, "Our God and God of Our Fathers." After this, he answers questions and tells the story of "The Source of Beauty." At this point, Schachter-Shalomi gives the next weeks assignment and goes on to give a detailed reading and commentary on "The True Torah" of the Maggid of Mezritch and tells stories of the Maggid. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 10 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of Hasidic Masters, Part 10 of 43. Lecture 4, Part C. In this continuation of class four, Schachter-Shalomi is still telling stories of the Maggid of Mezritch and giving a detailed commentary on "The True Torah" of the Maggid. He then goes on discuss other teachings and parables of the Maggid of Mezritch (related to "Let God's Glory Be for the World"). He speaks of the Maggid's son, Avraham the Angel in relation to this teaching. He then returns to his commentary on "The True Torah" of the Maggid. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 12 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 12 of 43. Lecture 5, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class five by answering questions on Jewish and Hasidic concepts encountered in the class readings. He discusses a seeming contradiction between the teachings of the Maggid of Mezritch and Pinhas of Koretz. After answering a few more questions, he turns his attention to Levi Yitzhak of Berditchev and sings his song called "Dudele" (The You Song). He talks a little bit about Reb Levi Yitzhak and then moves on to his teaching called "Teyku---Because Elijah Never Died!" He then explains a teaching of Moshe Leib of Sassov on arousing Love and Awe without naming him until later in the explanation. He goes on to speak about the fear of God and different types of fear. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 12 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 12 of 43. Lecture 5, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class five by answering questions on Jewish and Hasidic concepts encountered in the class readings. He discusses a seeming contradiction between the teachings of the Maggid of Mezritch and Pinhas of Koretz. After answering a few more questions, he turns his attention to Levi Yitzhak of Berditchev and sings his song called "Dudele" (The You Song). He talks a little bit about Reb Levi Yitzhak and then moves on to his teaching called "Teyku---Because Elijah Never Died!" He then explains a teaching of Moshe Leib of Sassov on arousing Love and Awe without naming him until later in the explanation. He goes on to speak about the fear of God and different types of fear. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 13 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 13 of 43. Lecture 5, Part B. In this continuation of class five, Schachter-Shalomi talks about Pinhas of Koretz' teaching "The Song of Songs is not Understandable." (He misspeaks and calls it a teaching of Moshe Leib of Sassov here.) Afterward, he answers questions on Jewish and Kabbalistic concepts (especially around evil and "The Breaking of the Vessels."). He then begins to discuss Reb Elimelekh of Lizhensk and the imaginal sacrifice recommended by Reb Elimelekh in "The Small Tzettle." He then sings a niggun to end the class. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 14 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 14 of 43. Schachter-Shalomi begins this class answering a question about a teaching of Reb Levi Yitzhak of Berditchev on God's preoccupation. He then discusses the issue of Jews, Non-Jews, and the "organismic" understanding of religion, telling a story of Reb Israel, the Maggid of Koznitz (misspeaks and says, Maggid of Mezritch) and talks about Sam Keen's stages of love. He then answers questions about the theory of paradigm shift in religion and the concepts of Emptiness and Nothingness. At this point, he begins to discuss Reb Shneur Zalman of Liadi, HaBaD Hasidism and the book called the Tanya. He discuses the inscription on the title page of the Tanya. This is followed by a short teaching about the Animal Soul and the Four Elements, which is followed by "The Niggun of the Four Stanzas" by Reb Shneur Zalman. He then looks at chapter 2 of the Tanya. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 16 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 16 of 43. In this continuation of class six, Schachter-Shalomi discusses the Animal Soul, after which he tells a story of Dov Baer, the son of Shneur Zalman of Liadi. He then speaks of the levels of the soul before entering into a longer discussion of the sefirot (Divine attributes), especially the upper three---Hokhmah ('wisdom'), Binah ('understanding'), and Da'at ('knowledge')---as related to the physical brain. This is followed by a discussion of the three garments of the soul (thought, word, and deed)---which may be positive, neutral, or negative---and the power of investment. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 18 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 18 of 43. Lecture 8, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins the class answering questions about "hating evil," "Subduing the Animal Soul," and "what is evil?" He then discusses Hokhmah, the 'H' of HaBaD, and goes on to talk about prayer. He tells a story of Rev. Howard Thurman on catalyzing prayer and then speaks of Reb Nahman of Bratzlav's teaching about turning teachings into prayer. This is followed by a discussion of material in the Tanya on the paradox of God's existence. He then discusses Reb Shneur Zalman's teaching, "What is Faith?" and the two wings of Love and Awe. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 19 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters. Part 19 of 43. Lecture 8, Part B. In this continuation of class eight, Schachter-Shalomi discusses how HaBaD Hasidism deals with depressive states, and talks about the power of confession, acts of contrition, and "over-joining". He then answers student questions and ends by discussing the end of the first book of the Tanya and introduces the second book. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 21 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 21 of 43. Lecture 9, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class nine by answering student questions on cultural filters and the use of the imagination when learning Hasidism, on the distinction between Jews and Non-Jews in the life and teachings of Reb Shneur Zalman, the levels of the soul and the elements, and the feminine in Judaism. He then turns to the last chapters of the Tanya and explores its difficulties, the idea of "crushing" the body, the "implicate order," and the power of mitzvot. He then introduces book two of the Tanya, Sha'ar ha'Yihud ve'Emunah, 'Gate to Unity and Faith,' on the Cosmology of HaBaD. He begins by singing the Hakhonoh Niggun, introduces the book, and speaks about "The Letters of Creation." Reb Zalman then turns to "Radical Amazement" and a discussion of "A Sun and a Shield is God." A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 29 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 29 of 43. Schachter-Shalomi begins class eleven with an introduction to the spirit of Rebbe Nahman of Bratzlav. He discusses Rebbe Nahman's emphasis on using the vernacular, sings a niggun, speaks of knowledge vs. experience, and tells Rebbe Nahman's "Tale of the Candelabra." He then plays his recording of "The Tale of the Seven Beggars" (the first two beggars' tales). There is then a class announcement, and Schachter-Shalomi begins to answer questions, especially on the nature of sacrifice. He then talks about the prophet Elijah and again plays his recording of "The Tale of the Seven Beggars" (the third beggar's tale). This is followed by student responses to "The Seven Beggars."

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 32 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 32 of 43. Lecture 12, Part A. Schachter-Shalomi begins class twelve with a discussion of d'vekut, 'adhering' to God, and speaks briefly about Reb Menachem Mendel, the Kotzker Rebbe and Abraham Joshua Heschel's book, A Passion for Truth, comparing the Kotzker and the Christian philosopher, Soren Kierkegaard. He then answers questions on "Voiding Strange Thoughts" in Reb Arele Roth's Ani Ma'amim before playing the video A Life Apart: Hasidism in America by Menachem Daum. A course in the Department of Religious Studies at the Naropa Institute, Spring, 1998. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 36 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 36 of 43.. Schachter-Shalomi begins class thirteen by answering questions about Hannah Rohel of Ludmir and women in Hasidism. He then talks briefly about the Kotzker Rebbe before reading "The Torah of the Menorah" on Hannah Rohel of Lubmir from his book, The Dream Assembly. At this point, Schachter-Shalomi plays a documentary about a modern woman exploring the lives of Hasidic women in Lubavitch (Crown Heights, Brooklyn).He then answers questions about Jewish Renewal and Reconstructionism, recounting his meeting with Rabbi Mordecai Kaplan, founder of Reconstructionist Judaism. See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 38 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 38 of 43. In this continuation of class thirteen, Schachter-Shalomi answers questions about Jewish Renewal, as well as questions about whether he feels Reb Ahrele Roth's idea of "Voiding Strange Thoughts" is irresponsible, on "traditions for export," doing halakhah (Jewish law) "in the Red," Lesbianism, and Counting the Omer. He then discusses Reb Mordecai Yosef of Ishbitz' teaching, "All is in the Hands of Heaven." See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 40 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 40 of 43. Class fourteen begins with a discussion of the Ishbitzer Rebbe, his son, Reb Ya'akov of Ishbitz, and the "Renewal" ways of his grandson, Reb Gershon Henokh of Radzyn. Schachter-Shalomi then turns to look at Hasidism and politics in the 20th Century, Rav Avraham Yitzhak Kook's view of secular Jews in Israel, and Hasidism and the Industrial Revolution. This is followed by an introduction to Reb Ahrele Roth (he also tells of meetings with Erich Neumann and Gershom Scholem) and his "mitzvot of the heart," his mystical intentions (kavvanot), and his prayer. Then Reb Kalonymous Kalmisch of Piasetzno is mentioned briefly before moving on to Reb Hillel Zeitlin, the Neo-Hasidic forerunner of Jewish Renewal. After this, there is a short discussion of Hasidic publishing after the Holocaust. He then goes on to answer questions about the relationship between Hasidism and Renewal, Renewal Judaism and outreach work, and the question of Uganda and Israel. There are then some announcements, and the question is asked, "What do we invest in the year 2025?" Schachter-Shalomi answers, "The hyphen" and goes on to explain about hyphenated-Jews. There is then as discussion of Rav Kook as a reincarnation of Reb Nahman of Bratzlav and the Renewal work of both Rebbe Nahman and Rav Kook. We then turn to the teaching of Reb Ahrele Roth on "blotting out Amalek." Then the question is asked, "Is there a connection between Existentialism and Hasidism?" See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 42 of 43
Description#1: Core Texts of the Hasidic Masters, Part 42 of 43. In this continuation of class fourteen, Schachter-Shalomi continues answering questions on the relationship between Hasidism and Existentialism, and on Renewal in relation to the Lubavitcher Rebbe. He reflects on Hasidism as it is presented in the films the students have watched and talks about Hasidic spiritual guidance for individual types, as well as Hasidic spirituality for women. He then discusses the differing concept of the Tzaddik in the teachings of Reb Shneur Zalman of Liadi and Rebbe Nahman of Bratzlav, and tells stories of his friend, Reb Gedaliah Kenig of Jerusalem, a Bratzlav manhig, 'leader.' See JRRZ0001S0056N0001 - N0043

Title#1: A Jewish Aids Aid, Part 1
Description#1: A Jewish Aids Aid, Part 1 . According to Schachter-Shalomi, these recordings were made at the suggestion of the young man identified only as Chayim on these tapes, who wished to create a Jewish Aids Aid concert. The concert did not happen, but these recordings of Schachter-Shalomi and Shlomo Carlebach singing and teaching on the topic give us a glimpse of what the concert may have been like.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Zalman in Berkeley, 1 of 18
Description#1: Zalman in Berkeley, 1 of 18. The first recording of the first event during a week in Berkeley. In one of the first gatherings of what became the Aquarian Minyan, Reb Zalman leads services, teaches on many subjects, and meets with local media and families. Part 1 is the first of 4 recorded files from the Friday night Kabbalat Shabbat service. He brings in discussions of Torah and consciousness(transpersonal sociology), Eastern spiritual practices, and more.

Title#1: Reb Shlomo Gainesville Hillel Concert. Part 3 of 6
Description#1: Reb Shlomo Gainesville Hillel Concert. Part 3 of 6. Concert Rabbi Shlomo gave at the University of Florida, Gainesville on 10/31/87. During the concert he tells stories, talks about music, Shabbos, davvening and singing. Side A 0:00 Singing 2:00 Shlomo talks about Shabbos and Noah. 7:30 Singing/praying 16:00 Singing continues. 22:00 A new song begins. 27:00 Shlomo talks about the upcoming Shabbos and the first mention of prayer in the Torah. 34:00 Shlomo tells a story about a family with irresponsible parents. 39:30 Singing 45:00 End of Side A Side B 0:00 Singing/music. 4:00 Shlomo tells two stories. The first is about Shlomo in Israel who met a non-religious Israeli soldier. 9:00 Singing 13:00 A new song begins. 16:00 Shlomo tells the second story about meeting a man in Haifa that just got out of a Siberian prison camp. 28:00 Shlomo sings a song from the story about the Siberian prisoner. 32:00 Shlomo continues to sing. 38:00 Shlomo sings a new song. 40:00 Shlomo talks about the messiah and then sings. 45:30 End of Side B
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Jewish Mysticism Night. 7th International Transpersonal Conference, Bombay, India. Part 3 of 5
Description#1: Jewish Mysticism Night. 7th International Transpersonal Conference, Bombay, India. Part 3 of 5. Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi, Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, and Rabbi David Zeller. Rabbi Schachter-Shalomi leads a service, incorporating guided imagery, singing and chanting. He talks about Gaian Consciousness, offers a blessing for the Dalai Lama and leads an experiential with toning and music. Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach takes over at the end of the recording. There are photos of this event in the Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Archives.

Description#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi and Huston Smith -Spirituality in Education Conference, 1 of 2. Session from the Spirituality in Education Conference at The Naropa Institute, May/June 1997, featuring Reb Zalman, Eve Ilsen, Huston Smith and John Cobb. It takes place on Shabbat. During the service Reb Zalman and Eve Ilsen lead prayers and songs. Reb Zalman and Huston Smith each give a 15 minute talk and discuss the relationship between religion, science and education.

Description#1: Reb Zalman Class at Elat Chayyim, 9 of 11. Rabbinical Training course taught by Reb Zalman at the Elat Chayyim Retreat Center, 7/26/96. Reb Zalman talks about moral development in Judaism and teaches from his book "Paradigm Shift". He talks about leadership and tells his students that what he hopes to achieve in his lifetime is "working on the template of the next phase of Yiddishkheit". He tells his students that they will have to continue this work. Tape 5 of 6

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Professional Training Group with Reb Zalman, 1 of 2
Description#1: Spiritual Eldering Professional Training Group with Reb Zalman, 1 of 2. Recording of a lunch meeting between Reb Zalman and some of his professional associates, possibly part of a larger conference. They talk about creating a Spiritual Eldering program and discuss recruitment, social change and forgiveness. The group discusses spiritual eldering and ways to advance the work. They also talk about the idea of a book that could be distributed with Zalman's teaching on spiritual eldering.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Spiritual Eldering Professional Training Group Meeting, 1 of 1
Description#1: Spiritual Eldering Professional Training Group Meeting, 1 of 1. Recording of a meeting between professional associates participating in a conference. Reb Zalman is not present at this meeting. The names of the participants are Marty, Elise and Gloria and Rachel. They discuss how to move forward with the work they are doing. They refer to a workbook being written by Reb Zalman and Howard Silverman. They discuss the best way to spread these spiritual eldering ideas, and how to ensure the repeated return of people that will attend the workshops they hold.

Reb Zalman lectures about gratitude and prayer, the importance of working on consciousness at this time and our relationship to God. They seem to be studying a text by one of the chasidic masters. Tape 5 of 7

Title#1: Saturday Morning class with Reb Zalman, 1 of 2
Description#1: Saturday Morning class with Reb Zalman, 1 of 2. A Class with Reb Zalman from 1/4/92, no other information on tape. Reb Zalman talks about Spinoza and moving from supernatural view to natural view of Torah. He talks about angels and a metaphor of "mansions of wisdom, riches, etc." He lectures on correlations between sephirot and the body and specifically the meaning of specific letters and vowels.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: On The Banks of the Jordan: Discussions on Jesus, Christianity, and Judaism, 1 of 2
Description#1: On The Banks of the Jordan: Discussions on Jesus, Christianity, and Judaism, 1 of 2. A lecture given by Reb Zalman on the banks of the Jordan River in Israel. Reb Zalman talks about the historical climate in Israel at the time just before Jesus' arrival on the scene, the overlapping similarities between Judaism and Christianity and the model of the "archetypal" versus "accessible" father/god. On Side B he talks about the death and resurrection of Jesus and about Paul, specifically how he worked to spread Christianity after Jesus' death.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Description#1: Spiritual Eldering, Canterbury-1991, 3 of 14. Recording of a group session at a Spiritual Eldering training workshop, Canterbury Center, Oviedo, Florida, May 6-10, 1991.
