Title#1: Spiritual Eldering, Canterbury-1991, 13 of 14
Description#1: Spiritual Eldering, Canterbury-1991, 13 of 14. Recording of a group session at a Spiritual Eldering training workshop, Canterbury Center, Oviedo, Florida, May 6-10, 1991. This appears to be the end of the final session of the training. The group members brainstorm on "Are You Saved?" and inter-generational work, Reb Zalman talks about creating a "Council of Elders" and asks the group members to reflect on what has been most important to them during the training. The session ends with joke telling. The session includes 2 biographical stories: one from Reb Zalman's visit to Mt. Sinai in 19784 and the other from his experience of a peyote ritual at the Taos Pueblo. Tape 8 of 8
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: David and Elaine's Wedding, Reb Zalman teaching, Shlomo-Rosh Hashanah, 1 of 2
Description#1: David and Elaine's Wedding, Reb Zalman teaching, Shlomo-Rosh Hashanah, 1 of 2. This tape includes three possible events. The first part is part of a wedding service, possibly David and Elaine Zeller's (material was identical to another tape labeled "David and Elaine's Wedding, #3". Zalman and Shlomo tell stories, lead songs, and offer insight to what a King is. Side A cuts in and out a couple of times, could be different events/dates. Side B seems to be Reb Shlomo teaching on or about Rosh Hashanah.

Title#1: Reb Zalman-The Craft of Niggunim, Part 1 of 2
Description#1: Reb Zalman-The Craft of Niggunim, Part 1 of 2. This is a collection of Niggunim and various songs sung by Reb Zalman and a group of individuals. Reb Zalman speaks about the craft of niggunim, forgiveness, and tells stories about conversations with God. Someone recites a teaching while another person sings a prayer. The recording ends with Reb Zalman's description of Shiva Shadchan and the special properties of the 15th of Av.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Sheva Bracha, Part 1 of 2
Description#1: Sheva Bracha, Part 1 of 2. Reb Zalman and a group of people are gathered together to study the Sheva Bracha blessings (7 blessings recited at wedding meals during the wedding week). This is possibly a meeting of the Aquarian Minyan, based on some of the content and references. Reb Zalman talks about the Sephirot, about what an Aquarian Minyan stag party would be like in the future, what an Aquarian Minyan wedding would be like, tells Chassidic and other stories and leads the prayers after meals.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Description#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 1 of 26, recorded March 8 - 13, 1976. Description#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 3 of 26, recorded March 8 - 13, 1976. The group sings a hymn, and Zalman plays the harmonica. Toward the end he discusses faith and prayer. 3/8/76.

Title#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 5 of 26
Description#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 5 of 26. Tape 3 of a 13 tape series on the Kabbalah, recorded March 8 - 13, 1976. Reb Zalman speaks about the values that one holds and the seriousness to which one holds these values. He does this through Hasidic stories, various metaphors depicting one striving for a certain level of morality, discussions regarding faith versus beliefs, and a niggun. 03/09/1976.

Title#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 23 of 26
Description#1: Rhythms of Life According to the Kabbalah, Part 23 of 26, recorded March 8 - 13, 1976. This recording takes place on shabbat Saturday afternoon/early evening after the Kabbalah seminar. Reb Zalman asks Gd, "Rabeynah Shalom", for many blessings, offer prayers of gratitude and says Kiddush. The group is invited to join a family for "Malevah Malchah" later in the evening. The group sing songs and musicians play and improvise instrumentally together. 3/13/76.

Title#1: JTS (Jewish Theological Seminary)-Visions of the Jewish Future Lunchtime Series. Part 1 of 2.
Description#1: JTS (Jewish Theological Seminary) - Visions of the Jewish Future Lunchtime Series. Part 1 of 2. Reb Zalman is called in as a guest to talk to a group at the Jewish Theology Seminary as part of their "Vision of the Jewish Future Lunchtime Series". He leads a niggun, says a prayer with them and discusses paradigm shift. He takes questions about davvenology, the Jewish Renewal movement, and cooperations with other religious people and non religious people to make the world a better place.

Title#1: Shavuot, Part 1 of 5
Description#1: Shavuot, Part 1 of 5. During this Shavuot service Reb Zalman talks about the fifty gates of understanding. He talks about the revelation on Mount Sinai and the exodus from Egypt. He talks about davvening and the group's schedule for the following day. Reb Zalman tells a short story about Victoria Day in Canada.

Title#1: Shavuot, Part 3 of 5
Description#1: Shavuot, Part 3 of 5. During this Shavuot service Reb Zalman starts with an exercise to pinpoint pain in the body. He takes questions from the group concerning Halakhah. Reb Zalman talks about Shavuot, Torah and prayer, and translates and discusses parts of the Torah. He shares a story about the early Kabbalists and the origin of some of the rituals for Shavuot, and talks about a meeting with Suzuki Roshi.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Shavuot, Part 5 of 5
Description#1: Shavuot, Part 5 of 5. During this Shavuot service Reb Zalman shares Hassidic stories with the group. He talks about the Baal Shem Tov and his death, and tells stories of the Baal Shem Tov and his niggunims. The perception of time and energy is discussed briefly. Reb Zalman says Kaddish for King David and leads a discussion on the Story of Ruth. On side B an unidentified man leads the group through the end of the observance of Shavuot, sharing a piece of writing about consciousness and violence, followed by chanting and another Hassidic story about someone after the passover Seder who did everything correctly except disposing of the crumbs.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: High Holidays, Part 17 of 28
Description#1: High Holidays, Part 17 of 28. High Holiday Services led by Reb Zalman, September, 1979. Tape says "Yom Kippur". Reb Zalman leads the group in prayers and songs in English and Hebrew. He talks about purifying the body with prayer and shares a personal story of being in Jerusalem at the Wall. He talks about congregants taking turns staying up all night to hold a vigil this evening. He later talks about the chain of transmission between generations and the responsibility to keep it going. He talks about a specific prayer, composed by Yom Tov of York, "Omnam Kayn", setting it to the melody of "God Save The Queen.
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 13 of 30
Description#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 13 of 30. This recording is from a seminar taught by Reb Zalman from July 15 to 24, 1975. Reb Zalman centers his discussion on the differences between somethingness and nothingness. He takes questions from the group and speaks about God's determination in whether or not something is "something" or "nothing." He mentions the book they are using - excerpts from the Zohar authored by Gershom Scholem. 7/17/1975

Title#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 15 of 30
Description#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 15 of 30. This recording is from a seminar taught by Reb Zalman from July 15 to 24, 1975. Reb Zalman discusses philosophical concepts-dualism versus non-dualism, in Jewish Mysticism. He talks about different concepts/views of God, reincarnation and the concept of " time stitching" as a different way of experiencing reality.The group sings a niggun from "papa's" heritage and he tells a personal story about introducing some Chassidic nigguns to a (Klezmer?) orchestra. 7/17/1975 to 7/18/1975
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Description#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 23 of 30. This recording is from a seminar taught by Reb Zalman from July 15 to 24, 1975. Title#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 25 of 30
Description#1: Seminar on Zohar. Part 25 of 30. This recording is from a seminar taught by Reb Zalman from July 15 to 24, 1975. Reb Zalman discusses the nature of good and evil, holiness and unholiness. He also talks about the concept of "Klippahs" - three klippahs in relation to evil. He refers to an article he wrote - "Patterns of Good and Evil" that contains much of the information he has talked about. 7/23/75

Title#1: Reb Nachman Seminar: Say Not Water, Water (Truth). Part 15 o 20
Description#1: Reb Nachman Seminar: Say Not Water, Water (Truth). Part 15 of 20. The title "Say not water, water" refers to one of Reb Nachman's seminal teachings on Truth. Description#1: Reb Nachman Seminar: Say Not Water, Water (Truth). Part 16 of 20. The title "Say not water, water" refers to one of Reb Nachman's seminal teachings on Truth. It comes from a quote by Rabbi Akiva from the Gemara about truth and falsehood. The recording also includes a song by Shlomo Carlebach and some teachings about Purim. Reb Zalman mentions a Torah and Dharma festival that will be taking place on Sunday, which is the 23rd of February, 1975. This recording is possibly from 2/20/75.

Title#1: Seminar with Aquarian Minyan. Part 9 of 29
Description#1: Seminar with Aquarian Minyan, March 7 - 13, 1977. Part 9 of 30. This is the sixth tape of a week-long seminar with the Aquarian Minyan in March, 1977 (note-Tape 5 was broken and not digitized). A group member, Jed, leads the group in a guided imagery experience to explore their feelings about relationships. Reb Zalman leads discussion exploring different kinds of relationships, contracts, marriage. A woman named Laurie shares her experiences of being in relationship but not married. Reb Zalman talks about how there is no role model in Judaism for women who are not married or are between relationships. 3/10/1977
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 1 of 5
Description#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 1 of 5. This is the first tape in a class that explores spirituality, Hassidism and how to get in touch with one's true purpose in life. The title comes from the expression "For Your Doomsday Good", referring to living your life as if you know it is at the end. Reb Zalman talks about teachings of mystics, shares Hassidic stories and songs, chants and dances. He teaches about Hassidism and talks about how Shabbos was observed in the time of the Baal Shem Tov. At one point he references a current movie (Meetings with Remarkable Men), playing at a local theater, the Surf Theater on 46th and Irving, in San Francisco. 6/5/1979
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 2 of 5
Description#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 2 of 5. This is the first tape in a class that explores spirituality, Hassidism and how to get in touch with one's true purpose in life. The title comes from the expression "For Your Doomsday Good", referring to living your life as if you know it is at the end. Reb Zalman talks about teachings of mystics, shares Hassidic stories and songs, chants and dances. He teaches about Hassidism and talks about how Shabbos was observed in the time of the Baal Shem Tov. At one point he references a current movie (Meetings with Remarkable Men), playing at a local theater, the Surf Theater on 46th and Irving, in San Francisco. 6/5/1979
Relation#2: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 3 of 5
Description#1: For Your Doomsday Good. Part 3 of 5. This is the second tape in a class that explores spirituality, Hassidism and how to get in touch with one's true purpose in life. The title comes from the expression "For Your Doomsday Good", referring to living your life as if Doomsday is at hand. In this tape, Reb Zalman discusses consciousness, the connections between Judaism and Astrology, and the similarities between Judaism and Buddhism. He also leads the group in a series of niggunim and songs in English and Hebrew. This tape includes performances from a traditional Jewish music group. 6/4 and 6/5/79

Title#1: Compilation of Israeli Music
Description#1:
This file contains a compilation of Israeli Music. There are 21 songs which include singers such as Esther Ofarim and Yehoram Gaon among others. Several of Esther Ofarim's songs are from her albums "Lights Out" or "Israeli Songs." Songs include: Hayu Leylot, Rakefet, Hu Lo Yada Et Shma, Shira Hanoded, Hareut, and Baladach Lachovesh.

Title#1: Zalman Teaching Nigunim (Melodies)
Description#1:
In this audio clip Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi leads students through nigunim (liturgical/spiritual melodies), and provides explanation of the melodies and their underlying intent. Other topics discussed include gematria (numeric correlation to Hebrew letters), models for the transmission of ideas, Kabbalah, and spirituality. Additionally, Zalman discusses the difference between deism, theism, and pantheism.
00:04:34 The Significance of “One” | 00:08:56 Zalman and Students Chanting a Nigun | 00:15:22 Two Models for Transmission of Ideas | 00:21:26 Zalman Reviews Melodies/Lyrics with Students | 00:29:51 Zalman Teaches New Nigun | 00:43:23 Another New Nigun | 00:50:35 Medieval Monastic Spirituality | 01:03:24 Zalman and Class Recite a Prayer | 01:11:57 Zalman on God’s Energy | 01:32:30 On Hebrew Letters

Title#1: Kabalah: The New Liturgy - Part 1
Description#1:
This audio recording contains Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discussing mysticism, Jewish and otherwise, and the integration of eastern practices into new Jewish liturgy/services. Discussion of Kabbalah and other mystical traditions is broken up by songs by the Sufi Choir and other music. Other topics of discussion include Kabbalah and the modern brain as well as a brief discussion of religion/spirituality during the 19th and 20th centuries. The audio ends abruptly and continues on part two.
01:26 The Root of Kabbalah | 05:02 Kabbalah and the Modern Brain | 08:56 The 19th and 20th Century | 15:57 Liturgy | 24:18 Integration of New Practices into Services

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Discussing Women in Judaism
Description#1:
In this recording Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses the history and modern place of women in Judaism. Concepts discussed include Eishet Chayil (Proverbs 31:10), the religious life of Jewish women, a lack of resources that previously existed for Jewish women, how can Jewish women be active in modern Judaism, the word Jew as a verb, Judaism in the home, and special foods for special occasions. The final ten minutes of the talk consist of a question and answer session with Zalman.
01:47 Zalman Discusses Eishet Chayil (A Woman of Valor) | 09:01 The Religious Life of Jewish Women | 17:18 Jewish Women Don’t Have the Resources They Used to Have | 20:14 What Can the Jewish Woman Do? | 26:57 Jew as a Verb | 37:33 On Judaism in the Home | 39:44 Special Foods for Special Occasions | 43:03 Question and Answer Session
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Prayer Service Part 1
Description#1:
This is part one of an audio recording of a prayer service with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. He begins by providing an introduction as well as an order to the service, however that order does not appear to be followed throughout the recording. The service begins with the chanting of a psalm in English. Following the psalm, the congregation chants several other melodies of which several appear to originate outside of traditional Jewish liturgy. Near the end of this recording the congregation chants "Shalom Aleichem" to the melody of "Shalom Chaverim." This part ends with the chanting of a nigun (liturgical melody) which then has English added to it.
02:21 Zalman Introduction and Instruction | 07:19 A Psalm in English | 20:47 Singing Praise God | 21:54 Multiple Chants | 34:44 Shalom Aleichem | 43:12 Chanting a Nigun
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Kabalah: The New Liturgy - Part 2
Description#1:
This recording begins with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi continuing his discussion from the first part on a new service and liturgy which he and others had created. The primary notion discussed in this recording is social change and its affect on liturgy. Like part one, topics are broken up by the placement of songs.
02:15 Social Change and Liturgy

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi Prayer Service Part 2
Description#1:
This is the second part of an audio recording of a prayer service with Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi. The recording begins amidst group singing. Shortly thereafter, the Barchu (call to worship) is said. After the Barchu, Zalman provides an exegesis on part of the Zohar. This is followed by the Amidah, which is subsequently followed by Kaddish, Kiddush, Motzi, and ends with a nigun (liturgical melody).
03:24 Barchu | 04:06 Exegesis on a Part of the Zohar | 16:29 Amidah | 32:45 Kaddish | 33:23 Kiddush, Motzi, and a Nigun

Title#1: Summer Breeze album by Seals & Crofts; Hebrew Songs and Sung Liturgy; Liturgy and hymns in English
Description#1:
This recording begins with the Seals and Crofts album "Summer Breeze." The album is followed by an assortment of liturgical songs in Hebrew, Yiddish, and English. Hebrew and Yiddish songs include a rendition of Psalm 116, Al Shlosha Devarim, Yigdal, and assorted Hebrew choral music.

Title#1: Radical Theology
Description#1:
In this recording Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi addresses a class on the concept of radical theology. He begins by discussing the three pillars of Judaism set forth in Pirkei Avot 1:2. Then Zalman moves into a discussion of radical theology where he addresses differing perspectives on theology including cause and effect theology and correlationist theology. He discusses Maimonides at length and moves into a discussion of the proposition of faith. Zalman then discusses philosophical perspectives on God and addresses the question of was it good that people were created? He concludes with an in-depth discussion of what he calls death of God theology for which he provides multiple theological perspectives. The final five minutes of the recording consist of open discussion.
00:03:20 Zalman Begins With Pirkei Avot 1:2 | 00:06:30 Introduction to Radical Theology | 00:14:52 Proposition of Faith | 00:24:52 God | 00:33:22 Was it Good For Man to Be Created? | 00:38:27 Death of God Theologians | 01:00:35 Open Discussion
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: The Psychedelic Experience
Description#1:
In this recording Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi discusses the psychedelic experience. He begins by providing some introductory stories and parables from archaic Jewish texts, discussing prophecies, and relaying the idea of worlds that preceeded and will succeed this world. After, he spends some time discussing Sufi mystics as well as Jewish mystics during the same time period. In the last 25 minutes of the recording, Zalman discusses Albert Hofmann's discovery of LSD, the work of Richard Alpert (Ram Dass) and Timothy Leary, mescaline, and psychedelic mushrooms. The recording ends abruptly in the midst of him speaking.
00:00:20 Introduction to the Psychedelic Experience | 00:13:19 Prophecies | 00:20:40 Worlds that Preceded this World | 00:30:19 Sufi Mysticism and Jewish Mystics of the Same Time Period | 00:36:10 Hasidism | 00:40:03 Psychedelic Drugs, Albert Hoffman, Richard Alpert, and Timothy Leary | 00:56:22 Relating Back Religious Transcendental Experiences
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Demonstration of Nusach for Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur
Description#1:
This recording is a selection of prayers from the Shacharit Service for Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur. The exact nusach is unknown, though potentially Hasidic in origin. The prayers are sung as the cantor would sing them: i.e. beginning in the middle of sentences (sometimes) to the end of paragraphs and reciting liturgy that is reserved for the cantor. The recording ends in the middle of the Torah reading for the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah.

Title#1: Tommy Glover (formerly Brother Josue) in Detroit, Michigan (ca. 1963-1964).
Description#1: Schachter-Shalomi notes that Glover felt he was being blocked from the priesthood and thus felt compelled to leave the monastery. Schachter visited with him in Detroit while there for a speaking engagement. A copy of this photo was sent to Father Thomas Merton with a handwritten note on the back which said, "It was a good meeting in Detroit. He is serious and cheerful." That copy is held at the Thomas Merton Center at Bellarmine University, Louisville, Kentucky. Approx. 5 in. x 7 in. black & white matte photo with a bent corner, slight warping, and imperfections on the image which may have come from the developing process. Digital photo scanned at 800dpi and cropped to photo area.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Behind Schachter-Shalomi and Ma Jaya is a Hanuman statue, a photo of Ma Jaya, a photo of Ma Jaya with Dr. Thomas Byrom (Billy Naga Baba), and two large photos of Neem Karoli Baba. Photo taken in the Dattatreya Temple at the Kashi Ashram in Sebastian, Florida. Approx. 3 1/2 in. x 5 in. matte color photo with minor warping. Digital photo scanned at 800dpi and cropped to photo area.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter-Shalomi seated with arms outstretched on a bench at the Mount Madonna Center, ca. 1999.
Description#1: The note on the back of the photo refers to its use on the cover of self-produced liner notes for The Tale of the Seven Beggars. On the back is written in ink, "6 Beggars / cropped, only outline". While Schachter-Shalomi identified Helena Foster as the photographer who took this photo (and the entire series), his wife, Eve Ilsen, believes that she took actually this photo. Approx. 5 in. x 7 in. color glossy photo with slight warping. Digital photo scanned at 800dpi and cropped to photo area.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.

Title#1: Rabbi Zalman Schachter speaking to people after a Hillel Foundation talk in Pittsburg, Pennsylvania in 1962 or 63.
Description#1: Schachter-Shalomi notes that the vest he is wearing was of his design and made for him. It was a corduroy pullover vest with tzitzit in the four corners. He also says this was a pivotal talk for him, during which he made a decision not to speak to his Lubavitch colleagues who were present, but to the needs of the assembled students. Approx. 8 in. x 10 in. black & white matte photo with white border, corner damage, cracks in surface, scratches and warping. Digital photo scanned at 800dpi and cropped to photo area.
Relation#1: Special Collections, Archives & Preservation, University of Colorado Boulder
Rights#1: Copyright and other restrictions may apply. User is responsible for compliance with all applicable laws. For information about copyright law, please see https://www.cusys.edu/DigitalLibrary/copyright.html.
